He halted again and bought from the old applewoman two Banbury cakes for a penny and broke the brittle paste and threw its fragments down into the Liffey. He halted and growled angrily: —For England... He halted before Dlugacz’s window, staring at the hanks of sausages, polonies, black and white. He halted near his daughter. He halted on sir John Gray’s pavement island and peered aloft at Nelson through the meshes of his wry smile. He handed her a shilling. He handed one to the boy. He handed the card through the brass grill. He handed the sheet silently over the dirty glass screen. He hangs his hat smartly on a peg of Bloom’s antlered head. He has a delicate mauve face. He has a house there too. He has a strain of it in his blood. —He has enough of them, she said. —He has, Father Cowley said. He has gnawed all. He has his bib destroyed. He has influence they say. He has legs like barrels and you’d think he was singing into a barrel. He has me heartscalded. He has money. —He has nothing to sit down on, sir. —He has nowhere to put it, you mug. He has recently escaped from Dr Eustace’s private asylum for demented gentlemen. He has revealed it in the sonnets where there is Will in overplus. He has seen a fair share go under in his time, lying around him field after field. He has some bloody horse up his sleeve for the Gold cup. He has that cabman’s shelter, they say, down there at Butt bridge. He has the forehead of a thinker. He has the key. He has the romantic Saviour’s face with flowing locks, thin beard and moustache. He has travelled. He has washed the upper moiety. He has written a really beautiful letter, a poem in itself, to the court missionary of the Reformed Priests’ Protection Society which clears up everything. He heard. He heard, deaf Pat. He heard her sad words, in held hat sad staring. He heard in a profound ancient male unfamiliar melody the accumulation of the past. He heard Joe Maas sing that one night. He heard more faintly that that they heard, each for herself alone, then each for other, hearing the plash of waves, loudly, a silent roar. He heard them as a boy in Ringabella, Crosshaven, Ringabella, singing their barcaroles. He heard then a warm heavy sigh, softer, as she turned over and the loose brass quoits of the bedstead jingled. He heard you pissed on his halldoor in Glasthule. He heaves his booty, tugs askew his peaked cap and hobbles off mutely. He, he, he! He held her hand. He held his caved hands a cubit from him, frowning: —I was tucking the rug under her and settling her boa all the time. He held his handkerchief ready for the coming... He held me and I was discoloured in four places as a result. He held out his copybook. He held the bowl aloft and intoned: —Introibo ad altare Dei. He held the page aslant patiently, bending his senses and his will, his soft subject gaze at rest. He held the page from him: interesting: read it nearer, the title, the blurred cropping cattle, the page rustling. He held unfurled his Freeman. He held up a forefinger of warning. He helped her to unload her tray. He hesitates. He hesitates amid scents, music, temptations. He himself? He himself, my lord, is a physical wreck from cobbler’s weak chest. He holds in his breath. He holds it towards fire. He holds my follies hostage. He holds out a forefinger. He holds out an ointment jar. He hoped she had nice weather in Rostrevor. He hopes to win in the gros lots. He hopped down from his perch and began to search his trouser pockets hastily. He hops. He horserides cockhorse, leaping in the, in the saddle. He howled, without looking up from the fire: —Kinch! He hummed: Là ci darem la mano La la lala la la. He hummed, prolonging in solemn echo the closes of the bars: Don Giovanni, a cenar teco M’invitasti. He hums cheerfully. He hurried on eagerly towards the Freeman’s Journal. He hurries out through the hall. He hustled the boy out and banged the door to. Heigho! Heigho! Heigho! Heigho! Heigho! Heigho! Heigho! Heigho! Heigho! Heigho! Height of a tower? He implored me to soil his letter in an unspeakable manner, to chastise him as he richly deserves, to bestride and ride him, to give him a most vicious horsewhipping. He indicates vaguely Lynch and Bloom. He infinitely preferred the sacred music of the catholic church to anything the opposite shop could offer in that line such as those Moody and Sankey hymns or Bid me to live and I will live thy protestant to be. He inquired if it was John Bull the political celebrity of that ilk, as it struck him, the two identical names, as a striking coincidence. He inserted his left hand into the left lower pocket of his waistcoat and extracted and replaced a silver coin 1 shilling, placed there presumably on the occasion 17 October 1903 of the interment of Mrs Emily Sinico, Sydney Parade. He insulted me but I forgive him. He insulted my lady friend. Heirloom. He is about to have a baby. He is a ghost, a shadow now, the wind by Elsinore’s rocks or what you will, the sea’s voice, a voice heard only in the heart of him who is the substance of his shadow, the son consubstantial with the father. He is all in all. He is a man of the very highest morale, Magennis. He is a mule, a dead gasteropod, without vim or stamina, not worth a cracked kreutzer. He is a new male: his growth is his father’s decline, his youth his father’s envy, his friend his father’s enemy. He is a rather quaint fellow on the whole, coy though not feebleminded in the medical sense. He is a wellknown cuckold. He is down on his luck at present owing to the mortgaging of his extensive property at Agendath Netaim in faraway Asia Minor, slides of which will now be shown. He is encrusted with weeds and shells. He is followed by a race of runners and leapers. He is going to visit the present duke, Piper says, and prove to him that his ancestor wrote the plays. He is going to write something in ten years. He is gone from mortal haunts: O’Dignam, sun of our morning. He is howled down. He is in my father. He is my double. He is nowhere: but an Edmund and a Richard are recorded in the works of sweet William. He is older now you and I may whisper it and a trifle stooped in the shoulders yet in the whirligig of years a grave dignity has come to the conscientious second accountant of the Ulster bank, College Green branch. He is our friend. He is pelted with gravel, cabbagestumps, biscuitboxes, eggs, potatoes, dead codfish, woman’s slipperslappers. He is practically a total abstainer and I can affirm that he sleeps on a straw litter and eats the most Spartan food, cold dried grocer’s peas. He is prematurely bald from selfabuse, perversely idealistic in consequence, a reformed rake, and has metal teeth. He is right. He is robed as a grand elect perfect and sublime mason with trowel and apron, marked made in Germany. He is running back to them. He is sausaged into several overcoats and wears a brown macintosh under which he holds a roll of parchment. —He is, says Joe. He is seated on a milkwhite horse with long flowing crimson tail, richly caparisoned, with golden headstall. He is sitting in their house, talking. —He is sitting with a sweet thing, Myles Crawford said, in a child’s frock. —He is sitting with Tim Healy, J. J. O’Molloy said, rumour has it, on the Trinity college estates commission. He is something like a fullgrown outdoor man. —He is, Stephen said. He is the ghost and the prince. He is young Leopold. He jerked short before the convent of the sisters of charity and held out a peaked cap for alms towards the very reverend John Conmee S. J. Father Conmee blessed him in the sun for his purse held, he knew, one silver crown. He jerks on. He jerks the rope. He jumped up and snatched the card. Hek! Hek! He keeps it free of weeds. He kicked open the crazy door of the jakes. He kills his mother but he can’t wear grey trousers. He kissed the plump mellow yellow smellow melons of her rump, on each plump melonous hemisphere, in their mellow yellow furrow, with obscure prolonged provocative melonsmellonous osculation. He kisses the bedsores of a palsied veteran. He knew them. —He knew what money was, Mr Deasy said. He knots the lace. He knows. He knows already. He knows and will call in His own good time. He knows it well too. He knows them all, faith. He knows which side his bread is buttered on though in all probability he never realised what it is to be without regular meals. —He knows which side his bread is buttered, says Alf. He knows your old fellow. He knows your old fellow. He laid both books aside and glanced at the third: Tales of the Ghetto by Leopold von Sacher Masoch. He laid her card and letter on the twill bedspread near the curve of her knees. He laid the brush aside and, laughing with delight, cried: —Will he come? He laid the dry snot picked from his nostril on a ledge of rock, carefully. He laps. He lauded almost extravagantly my nether extremities, my swelling calves in silk hose drawn up to the limit, and eulogised glowingly my other hidden treasures in priceless lace which, he said, he could conjure up. He laughed again at the now smiling bearded face. He laughed, lolling a to and fro head, walking on, followed by Stephen: and mirthfully he told the shadows, souls of men: —O, the night in the Camden hall when the daughters of Erin had to lift their skirts to step over you as you lay in your mulberrycoloured, multicoloured, multitudinous vomit! He laughed low: a sizar’s laugh of Trinity: unanswered. He laughed richly. He laughed to free his mind from his mind’s bondage. He laughed, unmarried, at Eglinton Johannes, of arts a bachelor. He laughs. He laughs. He laughs. He laughs. He laughs again and leers with lacklustre eye. He laughs loudly. He laughs, shaking his head. He lay back at full stretch over the sharp rocks, cramming the scribbled note and pencil into a pocket, his hat tilted down on his eyes. He lay but opened a red eye unsleeping, deep and slowly breathing, slumberous but awake. He lays aside the lapboard whereon he drafts his bills of costs for the eyes of master Goff and master Shapland Tandy, filing consents and common searches and a writ of Duces Tecum. He leads John Eglinton who wears a mandarin’s kimono of Nankeen yellow, lizardlettered, and a high pagoda hat. He leaned back and went on again, having just remembered. He leaned downward and read near her polished thumbnail. He leans out on tortured forepaws, elbows bent rigid, his eye agonising in his flat skullneck and yelps over the mute world. He leaps right, sackragman right. He leaves Florry brusquely and seizes Kitty. He led Father Cowley boldly forward, linked to his bulk. He led the way, admonishing: —We will sternly refuse to partake of strong waters, will we not? He left her and walked on. He left me on my ownio. He let go of the skin so that the profile resumed the normal expression of before. He let his head sink suddenly down and forward, hunching his shoulders and dropping his underjaw. He let out that Myler was on the beer to run up the odds and he swatting all the time. He let the bloodsmeared paper fall to her and dropped the kidney amid the sizzling butter sauce. He lies prone, his face to the sky, his hat rolling to the wall. He lifted his brown straw hat, saluting Paddy Dignam. He lifted his feet up from the suck and turned back by the mole of boulders. He lifted his gaze from the idle shells to the old man’s stare. He lifted his hands and said: All we can say is that life ran very high in those days. He lifted his voice above it boldly: —But, ladies and gentlemen, had the youthful Moses listened to and accepted that view of life, had he bowed his head and bowed his will and bowed his spirit before that arrogant admonition he would never have brought the chosen people out of their house of bondage, nor followed the pillar of the cloud by day. He lifted his yachtingcap and scratched his hindhead rapidly. He lifts a mooncalf nozzle and howls. He lifts her, carries her and bumps her down on the sofa. He lifts his arms. He lifts his ashplant high with both hands and smashes the chandelier. He lifts his mutilated ashen face moonwards and bays lugubriously. He liked thick giblet soup, nutty gizzards, a stuffed roast heart, liverslices fried with crustcrumbs, fried hencods’ roes. He liked to read at stool. He lilts, wagging his head. Heliotrope? He listened to her licking lap. He listens. He lives in number 2 Dolphin’s Barn. Hell, blast ye! He’ll come to all right. Hell did I put? Hellenise it. He’ll find himself on the horns of a dilemma if he meddles with a bull that’s Irish, says he. —He’ll get that advertisement, the professor said, staring through his blackrimmed spectacles over the crossblind. He’ll give a renewal for two months, he says. He’ll lose that cash. Hello. Hello. Hello. Hello. Hello. —Hello? Hello?... —Hello?... —Hello. Hello! Hello. Hello. —Hello, Alf. —Hello, Bloom. Hello, Bloom! —Hello, Bloom, Nosey Flynn said from his nook. Hello, Bloom, says he, what will you have? —Hello, Bob, old man, Mr Dedalus answered, stopping. —Hello, Bob, old man, Mr Dedalus answered, stopping. Hell of a racket they make. —Hello, Flynn. Hellohellohello amawfullyglad kraark awfullygladaseeagain hellohello amawf krpthsth. Hello, Jack. —Hello, Jack. —Hello, Jack, is that yourself? —Hello, Joe. Hello, Jones, where are you going? —Hello, M’Coy. —Hello, Ned. Hell open to christians they were having, Jimmy Henry said pettishly, about their damned Irish language. Hello, placard. Hello, seventyseven eightfour. —Hello, Simon, Father Cowley said. —Hello, Simon, Father Cowley said. HELLO THERE, CENTRAL! At various points along the eight lines tramcars with motionless trolleys stood in their tracks, bound for or from Rathmines, Rathfarnham, Blackrock, Kingstown and Dalkey, Sandymount Green, Ringsend and Sandymount Tower, Donnybrook, Palmerston Park and Upper Rathmines, all still, becalmed in short circuit. Hell’s delights! He’ll see you after at the D. B. C. He’s gone to Gill’s to buy Hyde’s Lovesongs of Connacht. Hell upon earth it is. He looked about him round his loud unanswering machines. He looked almost a saint and his confessionbox was so quiet and clean and dark and his hands were just like white wax and if ever she became a Dominican nun in their white habit perhaps he might come to the convent for the novena of Saint Dominic. He looked around. He looked at me. He looked at the cattle, blurred in silver heat. He looked at them. He looked at them, his wellshaped mouth open happily, his eyes, from which he had suddenly withdrawn all shrewd sense, blinking with mad gaiety. He looked away from me. He looked behind through the others. He looked calmly down on her bulk and between her large soft bubs, sloping within her nightdress like a shegoat’s udder. He looked down at the boots he had blacked and polished. He looked down intently into a stone crypt. He looked indecisively for a moment at their faces. He looked in Stephen’s face as he spoke. He looked on them from his drawling eye. He looked sideways in a friendly fashion at the sideface of Stephen, image of his mother, which was not quite the same as the usual handsome blackguard type they unquestionably had an insatiable hankering after as he was perhaps not that way built. He looked still at her, holding back behind his look his discontent. He looked towards the saloon door. He looked upon you to lust after you. He looked with vague hope up and down the quay, a big apple bulging in his neck. He looks at all for a moment, his right eye closed tight, his left cheek puffed out. He looks cheerful enough over it. He looks down on Stephen’s face and form. He looks round, darts forward suddenly. He looks round him. He looks up. He loved Ireland, he said, and he loved the Irish. —Help! he sighed. He lunged towards his messmates in turn a thick slice of bread, impaled on his knife. H. E. L. Y.’S filed before him, tallwhitehatted, past Tangier lane, plodding towards their goal. He made a comic face and whined, rubbing his knee: —The accumulation of the anno Domini. He made a mistake to fight the priests. He made improper overtures to me to misconduct myself at half past four p.m. on the following Thursday, Dunsink time. He made money. He made tracks heavily, slowly with a dumpy sort of a gait to the door, stepped heavily down the one step there was out of the shelter and bore due left. He makes a masonic sign. He makes the beagle’s call, giving tongue. He may suffer their memory to grow dim, let them be as though they had not been and all but persuade himself that they were not or at least were otherwise. He means that the love so given to one near in blood is covetously withheld from some stranger who, it may be, hungers for it. He met other schoolboys. He met schoolboys with satchels. He mews. He might be mad. He might be Mulligan. He might even have done for his man supposing it was his own case he told, as people often did about others, namely, that he killed him himself and had served his four or five goodlooking years in durance vile to say nothing of the Antonio personage no relation to the dramatic personage of identical name who sprang from the pen of our national poet who expiated his crimes in the melodramatic manner above described. —He might, Mr Dedalus said, if he hadn’t that squint troubling him. He mightn’t like it, though. He minuets forward three paces on tripping bee’s feet. He mounted to the parapet again and gazed out over Dublin bay, his fair oakpale hair stirring slightly. He moved a doll’s head to and fro, the brims of his Panama hat quivering, and began to chant in a quiet happy foolish voice: —I’m the queerest young fellow that ever you heard. He moved a little to the side of M’Coy’s talking head. He moved away, looking about him. He moved his head uncertainly. He moved to go. He, Mr Bloom, listened while he, Richie Goulding, told him, Mr Bloom, of the night he, Richie, heard him, Si Dedalus, sing ’Twas rank and fame in his, Ned Lambert’s, house. He mumbles confidentially. He mumbles incoherently. He murmured that he knew the name. He murmured then with blond delight for all: Between the acres of the rye These pretty countryfolk would lie. He murmurs.... in the rough sands of the sea... a cabletow’s length from the shore... where the tide ebbs... and flows ... He murmurs privately and confidentially. He murmurs.... swear that I will always hail, ever conceal, never reveal, any part or parts, art or arts... He murmurs vaguely the pass of Ephraim. He must be fed up with that job, shaking that thing over all the corpses they trot up. He mutters. Henceforth you are unmanned and mine in earnest, a thing under the yoke. Hence, in passivity, in economy, in the instinct of tradition, in unexpectedness, their differences were similar. Hence this. Hence those snores. He never existed. He never forgets a friend. He never heard. He nodded to himself as he drew off his trousers and stood up, saying tritely: —Redheaded women buck like goats. He nods. He, not me. He now will leave me. Henpecked husband. Henry. Henry. Henry! HENRY: All is lost now. HENRY: Caressing on his breast a severed female head, murmurs. Henry dear, do not deny my request before my patience are exhausted. Henry Flower. Henry Flower. Henry Flower combs his moustache and beard rapidly with a pocketcomb and gives a cow’s lick to his hair. Henry Flower Esq, c/o P. O. Westland Row, City. Henry gallant turns with pendant dewlap to the piano. HENRY: In a low dulcet voice, touching the strings of his guitar. Henry Menton, solr, Martin Cunningham, John Power, eatondph 1/8 ador dorador douradora must be where he called Monks the dayfather about Keyes’s ad Thomas Kernan, Simon Dedalus, Stephen Dedalus B. A., Edw. Henry wrote: Miss Martha Clifford c/o P. O. Dolphin’s Barn Lane Dublin. He of all men! He offended your memory. He offered to send me through the post a work of fiction by Monsieur Paul de Kock, entitled The Girl with the Three Pairs of Stays. He offers the other cheek. He opened it. He opened the letter within the newspaper. He opens his mouth, his head cocked. He opens it and shows it full of polonies, kippered herrings, Findon haddies and tightpacked pills. He other side of her. He ought to have done away with himself or lain low for a time after committee room no 15 until he was his old self again with no-one to point a finger at him. He ought to have either died naturally or on the scaffold high. He ought to physic himself a bit. He paid the debt of nature, God be merciful to him. He pants cringing. He passed a blind stripling opposite Broadbent’s. He passed an arm through the armstrap and looked seriously from the open carriagewindow at the lowered blinds of the avenue. He passed, dallying, the windows of Brown Thomas, silk mercers. He passed, discreetly buttoning, down the aisle and out through the main door into the light. He passed Grogan’s the Tobacconist against which newsboards leaned and told of a dreadful catastrophe in New York. He passed it along the table towards the old woman, saying: —Ask nothing more of me, sweet. He passed Saint Joseph’s National school. He passed the cabman’s shelter. He passed the Irish Times. He passes, struck by the stare of truculent Wellington, but in the convex mirror grin unstruck the bonham eyes and fatchuck cheekchops of Jollypoldy the rixdix doldy. He pats divers pockets. He patted his waistcoatpocket. He peeped quickly inside the leather headband. He peered from under his shaggy brows at the manuscript by his elbow and, muttering, began to prod the stiff buttons of the keyboard slowly, sometimes blowing as he screwed up the drum to erase an error. He peered sideways up and gave a long slow whistle of call, then paused awhile in rapt attention, his even white teeth glistening here and there with gold points. He perceived also that the awkward man at the other side of her was sitting on the edge of the seat. He performs juggler’s tricks, draws red, orange, yellow, green, blue, indigo and violet silk handkerchiefs from his mouth. He personally, being of a sceptical bias, believed and didn’t make the smallest bones about saying so either that man or men in the plural were always hanging around on the waiting list about a lady, even supposing she was the best wife in the world and they got on fairly well together for the sake of argument, when, neglecting her duties, she chose to be tired of wedded life and was on for a little flutter in polite debauchery to press their attentions on her with improper intent, the upshot being that her affections centred on another, the cause of many liaisons between still attractive married women getting on for fair and forty and younger men, no doubt as several famous cases of feminine infatuation proved up to the hilt. He pipes scoffingly. He pitched a broad coin down. He places a bag of gunpowder round his neck and hands him over to the civil power, saying. He places a hand in his waistcoat, posing calmly. He places a hand lightly on his breastbone, bows, and fondles his flower and buttons. He places a ruby ring on her finger. He places his arm on Private Carr’s sleeve. He plays pussy fourcorners with ragged boys and girls. He pleaded over returning phrases of avowal. He plodges through their sump towards the lighted street beyond. He plucks his lutestrings. He plumped him Dollard on the stool. He plunges his head into the gaping belly of the hanged and draws out his head again clotted with coiled and smoking entrails. He pointed his finger in friendly jest and went over to the parapet, laughing to himself. He pointed to two faces peering in round the doorframe. He points. He points. He points about him with grotesque gestures which Lynch and the whores reply to. He points an elongated finger at Bloom. He points his finger. He points to himself and the others. He points to the south, then to the east. He poked Mr O’Madden Burke mildly in the spleen. He poured into two teacups two level spoonfuls, four in all, of Epps’s soluble cocoa and proceeded according to the directions for use printed on the label, to each adding after sufficient time for infusion the prescribed ingredients for diffusion in the manner and in the quantity prescribed. He preferred himself to see another’s face and listen to another’s words by which potential narration was realised and kinetic temperament relieved. He pressed the same who pressed indulgently her hand, soft pedalling, a triple of keys to see the thicknesses of felt advancing, to hear the muffled hammerfall in action. He prodded a fork into the kidney and slapped it over: then fitted the teapot on the tray. He prolonged his pleased smile. He proposed to set up there a national fertilising farm to be named Omphalos with an obelisk hewn and erected after the fashion of Egypt and to offer his dutiful yeoman services for the fecundation of any female of what grade of life soever who should there direct to him with the desire of fulfilling the functions of her natural. He proves by algebra that Hamlet’s grandson is Shakespeare’s grandfather and that he himself is the ghost of his own father. He proves by algebra that Shakespeare’s ghost is Hamlet’s grandfather. He provokes my intelligence. He pulled back the jerky shaky door of the jakes and came forth from the gloom into the air. He pulled himself erect, went to it and, spinning it on its axle, viewed its shape and brass furnishings. He pulled the door to after him and slammed it twice till it shut tight. He pulled the halldoor to after him very quietly, more, till the footleaf dropped gently over the threshold, a limp lid. He pushed in the glass swingdoor and entered, stepping over strewn packing paper. He pushed past them to the files. He put down his name for a quid. He put his boot on what he had spat, wiping his sole along it, and bent, showing a rawskinned crown, scantily haired. He put his hand in a pocket anyhow not with the idea of finding any food there but thinking he might lend him anything up to a bob or so in lieu so that he might endeavour at all events and get sufficient to eat but the result was in the negative for, to his chagrin, he found his cash missing. He put it back in his sidepocket and took from his waistcoatpocket a nickel tinderbox, sprang it open too, and, having lit his cigarette, held the flaming spunk towards Stephen in the shell of his hands. He put me off it. He put on his glasses and gazed towards the metal bridge an instant. He puts Bohemia on the seacoast and makes Ulysses quote Aristotle. He puts his hand under black Liz and takes her fresh egg. He put the huge key in his inner pocket. He put the other coins in his pocket and started to walk on. He quenches his cigar angrily on Bloom’s ear. He raised his eyes and met the stare of a bilious clock. He raised his forefinger and beat the air oldly before his voice spoke. He raised his head firmly. He raises the ashplant. He raked his throat rudely, puked phlegm on the floor. Her ankles are linked by a slender fetterchain. Her antiquity in preceding and surviving successive tellurian generations: her nocturnal predominance: her satellitic dependence: her luminary reflection: her constancy under all her phases, rising and setting by her appointed times, waxing and waning: the forced invariability of her aspect: her indeterminate response to inaffirmative interrogation: her potency over effluent and refluent waters: her power to enamour, to mortify, to invest with beauty, to render insane, to incite to and aid delinquency: the tranquil inscrutability of her visage: the terribility of her isolated dominant implacable resplendent propinquity: her omens of tempest and of calm: the stimulation of her light, her motion and her presence: the admonition of her craters, her arid seas, her silence: her splendour, when visible: her attraction, when invisible. Her artless blush unmanned me. He rattled on: —Jehovah, collector of prepuces, is no more. Her beam is broad. Her blue scarf loose, laughing. Her boa uncoils, slides, glides over her shoulder, back, arm, chair to the ground. Her brandnew arrival is on her knee, post mortem child. Her cerebral lobes are not functioning. Her clothing consisted of. Her crocus dress she wore lowcut, belongings on show. Her death brought from him the scene with Volumnia in Coriolanus. Her door was open: she wanted to hear my music. Here. Here. Here. Here. Here. Here. Here. Here. Here. Here. Here? Here. Here! Here. Here. Here. Here. Here! Here. He read, marcato: —Characters: TOBY TOSTOFF a ruined Pole CRAB a bushranger MEDICAL DICK and two birds with one stone MEDICAL DAVY MOTHER GROGAN a watercarrier FRESH NELLY and ROSALIE the coalquay whore. He read on, seated calm above his own rising smell. He reads. He reads from right to left inaudibly, smiling, kissing the page. He read the other title: Sweets of Sin. He read the scarlet letters on their five tall white hats: H. E. L. Y. S. Wisdom Hely’s. He read where his finger opened. Here also over these craven hearts his shadow lies and on the scoffer’s heart and lips and on mine. Here are the darbies. Her ears ought to have tingled for a few weeks after. Her ear too is a shell, the peeping lobe there. Here, bugger off Harry. He recited jerks of verse with odd glances at the text: —Weep no more, woful shepherds, weep no more For Lycidas, your sorrow, is not dead, Sunk though he be beneath the watery floor... Here, citizen. He recorks himself. Hereditary taste. Here, don’t keep me waiting, damn you! He reflected that the progressive extension of the field of individual development and experience was regressively accompanied by a restriction of the converse domain of interindividual relations. He refuses to accept three shillings offered him by Joseph Hynes, journalist. Here goes. Here goes. Here he ponders things that were not: what Cæsar would have lived to do had he believed the soothsayer: what might have been: possibilities of the possible as possible: things not known: what name Achilles bore when he lived among women. —Here he was, miss Douce said, cocking her bronze head three quarters, ruffling her nosewings. Here I am. Here, I am not walking out to the Kish lightship, am I? Here, I can’t go fumbling at the damned eggs. Here, I can’t hold this little lot much longer. Here is all he... Here I watched the birds for augury. Here, Jock braw Hielentman’s your barleybree. Here, kiss that. Here lies poor dogsbody’s body. He remembered one night long ago. He remembered the initial paraphenomena? He removed his collar, with contained black necktie and collapsible stud, from his neck to a position on the left of the table. He removed his large Henry Clay decisively and his large fierce eyes scowled intelligently over all their faces. He removed the saucepan to the left hob, rose and carried the iron kettle to the sink in order to tap the current by turning the faucet to let it flow. —Here, Mr Dedalus said, handing her two pennies. Here, none of your tall talk. Here, Pat, return. He repeats. Here’s a good lump of thyme seasoning under the apron for you. Here, says he, take them to hell out of my sight, Alf. —Here, says Joe, doing the honours. Here see lost love. —Here’s fortune, Blazes said. Here’s good luck. —Here, she said. —Here, Simon, I’ll accompany you, he said. He rested an innocent book on the edge of the desk, smiling his defiance. —Here, Stephen said. Here’s the cops! Here’s this nobleman passed before. Here’s to us. He rests. He rests, disarmed of fatherhood, having devised that mystical estate upon his son. He resumed: —And, after blinking up at the sacred figure, Not a bloody bit like the man, says he. Here’s your stick. Here take your crutch and walk. Here, Terry, give us a pony. Here, thanks. Here the listener who was none other than the Scotch student, a little fume of a fellow, blond as tow, congratulated in the liveliest fashion with the young gentleman and, interrupting the narrative at a salient point, having desired his visavis with a polite beck to have the obligingness to pass him a flagon of cordial waters at the same time by a questioning poise of the head a whole century of polite breeding had not achieved so nice a gesture to which was united an equivalent but contrary balance of the bottle asked the narrator as plainly as was ever done in words if he might treat him with a cup of it. Here there try there here all try where. Here they are. Here, to buy yourself a gin and splash. He returns after a life of absence to that spot of earth where he was born, where he has always been, man and boy, a silent witness and there, his journey of life ended, he plants his mulberrytree in the earth. Hereupon he pawed the journal open and pored upon Lord only knows what, found drowned or the exploits of King Willow, Iremonger having made a hundred and something second wicket not out for Notts, during which time completely regardless of Ire the keeper was intensely occupied loosening an apparently new or secondhand boot which manifestly pinched him as he muttered against whoever it was sold it, all of them who were sufficiently awake enough to be picked out by their facial expressions, that is to say, either simply looking on glumly or passing a trivial remark. Hereupon Punch Costello dinged with his fist upon the board and would sing a bawdy catch Staboo Stabella about a wench that was put in pod of a jolly swashbuckler in Almany which he did straightways now attack: The first three months she was not well, Staboo, when here nurse Quigley from the door angerly bid them hist ye should shame you nor was it not meet as she remembered them being her mind was to have all orderly against lord Andrew came for because she was jealous that no gasteful turmoil might shorten the honour of her guard. Her every effort would be to share his thoughts. Here was that of which she had so often dreamed. Here we are. Here wet the deck and wipe it round! Here, what are you all gaping at? Her eyes are deeply carboned. Her eyes fixed themselves on him, wide in alarm, yet smiling. Her eyes on me to strike me down. Her eyes over the sheet. —Here you are, citizen, says Joe. —Here you are, says Alf, chucking out the rhino. Here, you were with him. Her falcon eyes glitter. Her fancyman is treating two Royal Dublins in O’Loughlin’s of Blackpitts. Her fansticks clicking. Her feeding cup and rubbing her mouth with the spoon. Her figure was slight and graceful, inclining even to fragility but those iron jelloids she had been taking of late had done her a world of good much better than the Widow Welch’s female pills and she was much better of those discharges she used to get and that tired feeling. Her first birthday away from home. Her first stays I remember. Her friend covering the display of. Her full lips, drinking, smiled. Her ghost at least has been laid for ever. Her glass of water from the kitchen tap when she had approached the sacrament. Her glazing eyes, staring out of death, to shake and bend my soul. —Her grave is over there, Jack, Mr Dedalus said. Her griddlecakes done to a goldenbrown hue and queen Ann’s pudding of delightful creaminess had won golden opinions from all because she had a lucky hand also for lighting a fire, dredge in the fine selfraising flour and always stir in the same direction, then cream the milk and sugar and whisk well the white of eggs though she didn’t like the eating part when there were any people that made her shy and often she wondered why you couldn’t eat something poetical like violets or roses and they would have a beautifully appointed drawingroom with pictures and engravings and the photograph of grandpapa Giltrap’s lovely dog Garryowen that almost talked it was so human and chintz covers for the chairs and that silver toastrack in Clery’s summer jumble sales like they have in rich houses. Her growing pains at night, calling, wakening me. Her hair is scant and lank. Her hand ceased to rummage. Her hand slides into his left trouser pocket and brings out a hard black shrivelled potato. Her hands passing slowly over her trinketed stomacher, a slow friendly mockery in her eyes. Her hands were of finely veined alabaster with tapering fingers and as white as lemonjuice and queen of ointments could make them though it was not true that she used to wear kid gloves in bed or take a milk footbath either. Her hand that rocks the cradle rules the. Her hat and head sank. Her hat sank at once. Her head dancing. Her he asked if O’Hare Doctor tidings sent from far coast and she with grameful sigh him answered that O’Hare Doctor in heaven was. Her heavy face, her eyes strike him in midbrow. Her high long snore. Her high notes and her low notes. Her hoarse loud breath rattling in horror, while all prayed on their knees. Her hub fifty odd and a methodist but takes the sacrament and is to be seen any fair sabbath with a pair of his boys off Bullock harbour dapping on the sound with a heavybraked reel or in a punt he has trailing for flounder and pollock and catches a fine bag, I hear. He rises slowly. Her large fan winnows wind towards her heated faceneck and embonpoint. Her maiden name was Jemina Brown And she lived with her mother in Irishtown. Her master, the Mona’s, said he was afraid his collision bulkhead would give way. Hermit with a platter of pulse keep down the stings of the flesh. Her mother’s birthday that was and Charley was home on his holidays and Tom and Mr Dignam and Mrs and Patsy and Freddy Dignam and they were to have had a group taken. —Her mouth glued on his in a luscious voluptuous kiss while his hands felt for the opulent curves inside her déshabillé. Her name and address she then told with my tooraloom tooraloom tay. Her nature. —He rode down through Dame walk, the refined accent said, if my memory serves me. Herod’s slaughter of the innocents were the truer name. Her olive face is heavy, slightly sweated and fullnosed with orangetainted nostrils. He rooted in the sand, dabbling, delving and stopped to listen to the air, scraped up the sand again with a fury of his claws, soon ceasing, a pard, a panther, got in spousebreach, vulturing the dead. Her pale blue scarf loose in the wind with her hair. Her petticoat. Her posies too! Herr Bleibtreu, the man Piper met in Berlin, who is working up that Rutland theory, believes that the secret is hidden in the Stratford monument. Herring’s blush. Her secrets: old featherfans, tasselled dancecards, powdered with musk, a gaud of amber beads in her locked drawer. Her shapely fingernails reddened by the blood of squashed lice from the children’s shirts. Her shoes were the newest thing in footwear Edy Boardman prided herself that she was very petite but she never had a foot like Gerty MacDowell, a five, and never would ash, oak or elm with patent toecaps and just one smart buckle over her higharched instep. Her sleeve falling from gracing arms, reveals a white fleshflower of vaccination. Her slim legs running up the staircase. Her songs. Her son was the substance. Her sowcunt barks. Her spoon ceased to stir up the sugar. Her stockings are loose over her ankles. Her the lady’s eyes, dark, large, looked at Stephen, about to smile about something to be admired, Lafayette of Westmoreland street, Dublin’s premier photographic artist, being responsible for the esthetic execution. Her to forgive now he craved with good ground of her allowed that that of him swiftseen face, hers, so young then had looked. Her tomboy oaths. He rubs grimly his grappling hands, knobbed with knuckledusters. He runs to the piano and takes his ashplant, beating his foot in tripudium. He rushes against the mauve shade, flapping noisily. He rushes towards Stephen, fist outstretched, and strikes him in the face. He rustled the pleated pages, jerking his chin on his high collar. Her very soul is in her eyes and she would give worlds to be in the privacy of her own familiar chamber where, giving way to tears, she could have a good cry and relieve her pentup feelings though not too much because she knew how to cry nicely before the mirror. Her voice floating out. Her wavyavyeavyheavyeavyevyevyhair un comb:’d. Her wellturned ankle displayed its perfect proportions beneath her skirt and just the proper amount and no more of her shapely limbs encased in finespun hose with highspliced heels and wide garter tops. Her wet lips tittered: —He’s killed looking back. Her widow’s mite. Her woman’s instinct told her that she had raised the devil in him and at the thought a burning scarlet swept from throat to brow till the lovely colour of her face became a glorious rose. Her words rang out crystalclear, more musical than the cooing of the ringdove, but they cut the silence icily. —He’s a bloody dark horse himself, says Joe. —He’s a bloody ruffian, I say, to take away poor little Willy Dignam. He’s a caution to rattlesnakes. He’s a cross between Lobengula and Lynchehaun. —He’s a cultured allroundman, Bloom is, he said seriously. He’s a gentleman, a poet. —He’s a hero, he said simply. He said. He said also how at the end of the second month a human soul was infused and how in all our holy mother foldeth ever souls for God’s greater glory whereas that earthly mother which was but a dam to bear beastly should die by canon for so saith he that holdeth the fisherman’s seal, even that blessed Peter on which rock was holy church for all ages founded. He said and then lifted he in his rude great brawny strengthy hands the medher of dark strong foamy ale and, uttering his tribal slogan Lamh Dearg Abu, he drank to the undoing of his foes, a race of mighty valorous heroes, rulers of the waves, who sit on thrones of alabaster silent as the deathless gods. He said he’d try to come. He said he’ll be in the Ormond at four. He said nothing. He said softly in the bare hall: —I’m going round the corner. He said that he had seen from the gods my peerless globes as I sat in a box of the Theatre Royal at a command performance of La Cigale. He’s always bad then. He’s always doing a good turn for someone. He’s a minister in the country somewhere. He’s an excellent brother. He’s an excellent man to organise. He sang that song lovely, murmured Mina. He’s a nice pattern of a Romeo and Juliet. He’s an Irishman. He sank two lumps of sugar deftly longwise through the whipped cream. —He’s a perverted jew, says Martin, from a place in Hungary and it was he drew up all the plans according to the Hungarian system. He’s a proboer. He’s a professor. He’s a professor out of the college. He’s a safe man, I’d say. He’s as bad as old Antonio. He’s as bad as Parnell was. He’s as like it as damn it. He sat down, cut and buttered a slice of the loaf. He sat on a corner of the unlit desk, reading aloud joyfully: —The sentimentalist is he who would enjoy without incurring the immense debtorship for a thing done. —He’s at rest, he said, in the middle of his people, old Dan O’. He saved men from drowning and you shake at a cur’s yelping. He saved the situa. He saw him once on the auspicious occasion when they broke up the type in the Insuppressible or was it United Ireland, a privilege he keenly appreciated, and, in point of fact, handed him his silk hat when it was knocked off and he said Thank you, excited as he undoubtedly was under his frigid exterior notwithstanding the little misadventure mentioned between the cup and the lip: what’s bred in the bone. He saw his trunk and limbs riprippled over and sustained, buoyed lightly upward, lemonyellow: his navel, bud of flesh: and saw the dark tangled curls of his bush floating, floating hair of the stream around the limp father of thousands, a languid floating flower. He’s a whitearsed bugger. He saw in a quick young male familiar form the predestination of a future. He saw not bronze. He saw not gold. He saw their speeds, backing king’s colours, and shouted with the shouts of vanished crowds. He saw them three by three, approaching girls, in green, in rose, in russet, entwining, per l’aer perso, in mauve, in purple, quella pacifica oriafiamma, gold of oriflamme, di rimirar fè più ardenti. He saw the priest bend down and kiss the altar and then face about and bless all the people. He saw the priest stow the communion cup away, well in, and kneel an instant before it, showing a large grey bootsole from under the lace affair he had on. He says: il se promène, lisant au livre de lui-même, don’t you know, reading the book of himself. He says it’s very clever. He says this, a censor of morals, a very pelican in his piety, who did not scruple, oblivious of the ties of nature, to attempt illicit intercourse with a female domestic drawn from the lowest strata of society! He’s back from Paris. He’s been known to put his hand down too to help a fellow. He’s behind with Ned Lambert and Hynes. He’s Bloom! He’s bringing the programme. He scalded and rinsed out the teapot and put in four full spoons of tea, tilting the kettle then to let the water flow in. He scarcely looks thirtyone. He’s coming in the afternoon. He’s covered with shavings anyhow. He scrambled up by the stones, water glistening on his pate and on its garland of grey hair, water rilling over his chest and paunch and spilling jets out of his black sagging loincloth. He scratched imprecisely with his right hand, though insensible of prurition, various points and surfaces of his partly exposed, wholly abluted skin. He scratches himself with crossed arms at his ribs, grimacing, and exclaims: I’m suffering the agony of the damned. He’s dead. He’s dead, he said. —He’s dead nuts on sales, M’Coy said. He’s dead nuts on that. He searches his pockets vaguely. He see. He seehears lipspeech. He seizes solitary paper. —He’s English, Buck Mulligan said, and he thinks we ought to speak Irish in Ireland. He set off again to walk by Stephen’s side. He settles down his goffered ruffs and moistens his lips with a passage of his amorous tongue. He’s fainted! He’s from beyant Boyne water. He’s getting his pleasure. He’s giving Sceptre today. He’s going to holler. He’s going to say a word to long John to get him to take those two men off. He’s going to take an action for ten thousand pounds, he says. He’s gone. He’s gone. He’s gone from us. He’s gone over to the lying-in hospital they told me. He’s gone to Gill’s to buy it. He’s gone too. He’s got a coughmixture with a punch in it for you, my friend, in his back pocket. He shakes hands with Private Carr, Private Compton, Stephen, Bloom and Lynch. He shaved evenly and with care, in silence, seriously. He shaved warily over his chin. He shook his constraint from him nervously. He shore away the burnt flesh and flung it to the cat. He shot from it two crowns and two shillings. He shot his bolt, I can tell you! He should be soundly trounced! He shoulders the second watch gently. He should have read that before lunch. He shouts. He shoves his arm in a bidder’s face. He showed them the rising column of disks on the right. He shows all that he is wearing green socks. He shut his eyes tight in delight, his body shrinking, and blew a sweet chirp from his lips. He sighed aside: —Ah me! He sighed down his nose: they never understand. He sighs. He sighs and stretches himself, then murmurs thickly with prolonged vowels. He sighs, draws back and stares sideways down with dropping underjaw. He signed to the waiting jarvey who chucked at the reins and set on towards Lord Edward street. He sings. He’s in his sanctum with Lenehan. He’s inside with his friend. —He’s in the craft, he said. He’s in there now with his lawbooks finding out the law of libel. —He’s in with a lowdown crowd, Mr Dedalus snarled. —He’s Irish, the seaman bold affirmed, staring still in much the same way and nodding. He sits tinily on the pianostool and lifts and beats handless sticks of arms on the keyboard, nodding with damsel’s grace, his bowknot bobbing. He skipped off the gunrest and looked gravely at his watcher, gathering about his legs the loose folds of his gown. He slapped a piebald haunch quivering near him and cried: —Woa, sonny! He slaps her face. He slid his chalice brisk away, grasped his change. He slid in a disk for himself: and watched it shoot, wobble, ogle, stop: four. He slid it into the left slot for them. He slipped card and letter into his sidepocket, reviewing again the soldiers on parade. He’s looking. He slunk back in a curve. He smellsipped the cordial juice and, bidding his throat strongly to speed it, set his wineglass delicately down. He smiled at bronze’s teabathed lips, at listening lips and eyes: —The élite of Erin hung upon his lips. He smiled, glancing askance at her mocking eyes. He smiled on all sides equally. He smiled, pleasing himself. He smiled, pouring. He smiled with troubled affection at the kitchen window. He smiles uneasily. He smites with his bicycle pump the crayfish in his left hand. He’s my pal. He snaps his jaws suddenly on the air. He sneezes. He sniffs. He sniffs. He’s no eunuch. He’s no more dead than you are. He’s not going out in bluey specs with the sweat rolling off him to baptise blacks, is he? He’s not one of your common or garden... you know... —He’s not too bad, Nosey Flynn said, snuffling it up. He’s off. He’s on for a razzle backache spree. He’s on point duty up and down there for the last ten minutes. He sopped other dies of bread in the gravy and ate piece after piece of kidney. Hesouls, shesouls, shoals of souls. He’s out in pampooties to murder you. —He’s out of that long ago, Nosey Flynn said. He’s over all his troubles. He spat blank. He speaks the words to Burbage, the young player who stands before him beyond the rack of cerecloth, calling him by a name: Hamlet, I am thy father’s spirit, bidding him list. He sped off towards Conway’s corner. He spits in contempt. He spluttered to the air: —O, the chinless Chinaman! He sprang it open with his thumb and offered it. —He’s pretty well on, professor MacHugh said in a low voice. He springs off into vacuum. He sprinkled it through his fingers ringwise from the chipped eggcup. He squirms. He’s quite enthusiastic, don’t you know, about Hyde’s Lovesongs of Connacht. He’s rather blasphemous. He’s right. He’s stinking with money and thinks you’re not a gentleman. He staggers a pace back. He staggers forward, dragging them with him. He stands aside at the threshold. He stands at Cormack’s corner, watching. He stands before a lighted house, listening. He stared at them proudly, piled stone mammoth skulls. He stated that this had greatly perturbed his peace of mind in the other region and earnestly requested that his desire should be made known. He stepped aside nimbly. He stepped out. He stepped out of the carriage, replacing the newspaper his other hand still held. He stepped swiftly off, his eyes coming to blue life as they passed a broad sunbeam. He steps forward. He steps left, ragsackman left. He’s the backbone of our empire. He’s the grandest thing yet and don’t you forget it. He’s the only man in Dublin has it. He’s the organiser in point of fact. He’s there, all that was mortal of him. He sticks out a flickering phosphorescent scorpion tongue, his hand on his fork. He stood a moment unseeing by the cold black marble bowl while before him and behind two worshippers dipped furtive hands in the low tide of holy water. He stood aside watching their blind masks pass down the aisle, one by one, and seek their places. He stood at Fleet street crossing. He stood beside them beaming, on them first and on his roomy clothes from points of which Mr Dedalus flicked fluff, saying: —They were made for a man in his health, Ben, anyhow. He stood by the nextdoor girl at the counter. He stood in the porch and watched the laggard hurry towards the scrappy field where sharp voices were in strife. He stood looking in at the two puckers stripped to their pelts and putting up their props. He stood suddenly, his feet beginning to sink slowly in the quaking soil. He stood to read the card in his hand. He stood up. He stood up and gave a shout of nervous laughter to which their cries echoed dismay. He stood up, gravely ungirdled and disrobed himself of his gown, saying resignedly: —Mulligan is stripped of his garments. He stood up, undoing the waistband of his trousers. He stooped and gathered them. He stooped and lifted the valance. He stoops and, peering, pokes with his fan rudely under the fat suet folds of Bloom’s haunches. He stopped. He stopped at each, took out a communion, shook a drop or two are they in water? off it and put it neatly into her mouth. He stopped at the stairfoot. He stopped, sniffed, stalked round it, brother, nosing closer, went round it, sniffling rapidly like a dog all over the dead dog’s bedraggled fell. He stops dead. He stops, points at Lynch’s cap, smiles, laughs. He stops, sneezes. He’s traipsing all round Dublin with a postcard someone sent him with U. p: up on it to take a li... He stretched more, more. He stretches out his arms, sighs again and curls his body. He strides off on stiff cavalry legs. He strike a telegramboy paddock wire big bug Bass to the depot. He strikes a match and proceeds to light the cigarette with enigmatic melancholy. He strode away from them towards the window. He strode on for Clare street, grinding his fierce word. He strolled. He strolled out of the postoffice and turned to the right. He strolled out of the shop, the newspaper baton under his armpit, the coolwrappered soap in his left hand. He strolled out to the doorway. He struggled out of his shirt and flung it behind him to where his clothes lay. He studded under each lifted strip yellow blobs. He stumbles on the steps, recovers, plunges into gloom. He sucks a red jujube. He sued a fellowplayer for the price of a few bags of malt and exacted his pound of flesh in interest for every money lent. He suffered her to overtake him without surprise and thrust his dull grey beard towards her, his loose jaw wagging as he spoke earnestly. He’s up in Dottyville with Connolly Norman. He swears His Highness not His Lordship by saint Patrick. He’s well up in history, faith. He’s well worth seeing, mind you. He swept the mirror a half circle in the air to flash the tidings abroad in sunlight now radiant on the sea. He swerved to the right. He swerves, sidles, stepaside, slips past and on. He’s white. He swoops uncertainly through the air, wheeling, uttering cries of heartening, on strong ponderous buzzard wings. He’s writing a book about the Fitzgeralds he told me. He swung himself forward in vigorous jerks, halted, lifted his head towards a window and bayed deeply: —home and beauty. He swung himself violently forward past Katey and Boody Dedalus, halted and growled: —home and beauty. He takes breath with care and goes forward slowly towards the lampset siding. He takes great pride, quite legitimate, out of you. He takes off his high grade hat, saluting. He takes part in a stomach race with elderly male and female cripples. He takes up the poundnote. He tapped his chest sadly. He tapped his savingsbox against his thumbnail. He taps her on the shoulder with his fan. He taps his brow. He taps his parchmentroll energetically. He tasted a spoonful from the creamy cone of his cup. He thanked her and glanced rapidly at the typed envelope. He thinks of a drizzling night in Hatch street, hard by the bonded stores there, the first. He thinks you’re not a gentleman. He thought, but not for long, of soldiers and sailors, whose legs had been shot off by cannonballs, ending their days in some pauper ward, and of cardinal Wolsey’s words: If I had served my God as I have served my king He would not have abandoned me in my old days. He thought that he thought that he was a jew whereas he knew that he knew that he knew that he was not. He thous and thees her with grave husbandwords. He threw an odd eye at the same time now and then at Stephen’s anything but immaculately attired interlocutor as if he had seen that nobleman somewhere or other though where he was not in a position to truthfully state nor had he the remotest idea when. He threw down among them a crumpled paper ball. He threw it. He threw it on the road. He throws a leg astride and, pressing with horseman’s knees, calls in a hard voice. He throws a shilling on the table and starts. He thrust back quick Agendath. He thrusts out a figged fist and foul cigar. He thrust the sheets back and went into the inner office. He thumps the parapet. He told her that time when she told him about that in confession, crimsoning up to the roots of her hair for fear he could see, not to be troubled because that was only the voice of nature and we were all subject to nature’s laws, he said, in this life and that that was no sin because that came from the nature of woman instituted by God, he said, and that Our Blessed Lady herself said to the archangel Gabriel be it done unto me according to Thy Word. He told me about, hold on, Swinburne, was it, no? He told me to be a good son to ma. He told me when they cut him down after the drop it was standing up in their faces like a poker. He told them of the race. He took a cigarette from the case. He took a cigarette from the open case. He took a page up from the pile of cut sheets: the model farm at Kinnereth on the lakeshore of Tiberias. He took a red carnation from the tall stemglass. He took his ordinary at a boilingcook’s and if he had but gotten into him a mess of broken victuals or a platter of tripes with a bare tester in his purse he could always bring himself off with his tongue, some randy quip he had from a punk or whatnot that every mother’s son of them would burst their sides. He took it to heart, pined away. He took off his silk hat and, blowing out impatiently his bushy moustache, welshcombed his hair with raking fingers. He took out his handkerchief to dab his nose. He took out of his mouth the pulpy quid and, lodging it between his teeth, bit ferociously: —Khaan! He took the coverless book from her hand. He took the eager card, glanced, not saw, laid down unglanced, looked, asked, creaked, asked: —Is he?... He took the hilt of his ashplant, lunging with it softly, dallying still. —He took umbrage at something or other, that muchinjured but on the whole eventempered person declared, I let slip. He tore away half the prize story sharply and wiped himself with it. He tore the flower gravely from its pinhold smelt its almost no smell and placed it in his heart pocket. He tossed it off the pan on to a plate and let the scanty brown gravy trickle over it. He tossed the tissues on to the table. He touched the thin elbow gently: then took the limp seeing hand to guide it forward. He touched to fair miss Kennedy a rim of his slanted straw. He touches the keys again. He toured the wide world with Hengler’s Royal Circus. He tried his hardest to recollect for the moment whether he had lost as well he might have or left because in that contingency it was not a pleasant lookout, very much the reverse in fact. He trips awkwardly. He trips up a fat policeman. He trod the worn steps, pushed the swingdoor and entered softly by the rere. He trotted forward and, lifting again his hindleg, pissed quick short at an unsmelt rock. He tugged swiftly at Stephen’s ashplant in farewell and, running forward to a brow of the cliff, fluttered his hands at his sides like fins or wings of one about to rise in the air, and chanted: —Goodbye, now, goodbye! He turned. He turned abruptly his grey searching eyes from the sea to Stephen’s face. He turned a happy patch’s smirk to Stephen, saying: —The disguise, I fear, is thin. He turned a long you are wrong gaze on Stephen of timorous dark pride at the soft impeachment with a glance also of entreaty for he seemed to glean in a kind of a way that it wasn’t all exactly. He turned and halted by the slanted bookcart. He turned away and sauntered across the road. He turned away from the others, who probably… and spoke nearer to, so as the others… in case they… —Jews, he softly imparted in an aside in Stephen’s ear, are accused of ruining. He turned back quickly, coughing, laughing, his lifted arms waving to the air. He turned back the other side of the card, picture, and passed it along to Stephen. He turned, bounded back, came nearer, trotted on twinkling shanks. He turned Combridge’s corner, still pursued. He turned from the morning noises of the quayside and walked through Lime street. He turned from the tray, lifted the kettle off the hob and set it sideways on the fire. He turned his angry white moustache. He turned his body half round, shut up his right eye completely. He turned his face over a shoulder, rere regardant. He turned into Cumberland street and, going on some paces, halted in the lee of the station wall. He turned northeast and crossed the firmer sand towards the Pigeonhouse. He turned over the smudged pages. He turned suddenly from a chip of strawberries, drew a gold watch from his fob and held it at its chain’s length. He turned the pages back. He turned to both. He turned to J. J. O’Molloy and asked: —Well, Jack. He turned to Stephen and asked blandly: —Is this the day for your monthly wash, Kinch? He turned to Stephen and asked in a fine puzzled voice, lifting his brows: —Can you recall, brother, is mother Grogan’s tea and water pot spoken of in the Mabinogion or is it in the Upanishads? He turned to Stephen and said: —Seriously, Dedalus. He turned to Stephen, saying, as he pulled down neatly the peaks of his primrose waistcoat: —You couldn’t manage it under three pints, Kinch, could you? He turned to the right and on his right Master Dignam turned, his cap awry, his collar sticking up. He turned towards Myles Crawford and said: —You know Gerald Fitzgibbon. He turned towards Stephen and said: —Look at the sea. He turns gravely to the first watch. He turns on his left side, sighing, doubling himself together. He turns to a figure in the crowd, appealing. He turns to his subjects. He twirls in reversed directions a clouded cane, then wedges it tight in his oxter. He twists her arm. He twitches. He unbraced successively each of six minus one braced trouser buttons, arranged in pairs, of which one incomplete. He unbuttoned successively in reversed direction waistcoat, trousers, shirt and vest along the medial line of irregular incrispated black hairs extending in triangular convergence from the pelvic basin over the circumference of the abdomen and umbilicular fossicle along the medial line of nodes to the intersection of the sixth pectoral vertebrae, thence produced both ways at right angles and terminating in circles described about two equidistant points, right and left, on the summits of the mammary prominences. He uncorks himself behind: then, contorting his features, farts loudly. He understood however from all he heard that Dr Mulligan was a versatile allround man, by no means confined to medicine only, who was rapidly coming to the fore in his line and, if the report was verified, bade fair to enjoy a flourishing practice in the not too distant future as a tony medical practitioner drawing a handsome fee for his services in addition to which professional status his rescue of that man from certain drowning by artificial respiration and what they call first aid at Skerries, or Malahide was it?, was, he was bound to admit, an exceedingly plucky deed which he could not too highly praise, so that frankly he was utterly at a loss to fathom what earthly reason could be at the back of it except he put it down to sheer cussedness or jealousy, pure and simple. He undoes the noose. He unrolled the newspaper baton idly and read idly: What is home without Plumtree’s Potted Meat? He unrolls his parchment rapidly and reads, his glowworm’s nose running backwards over the letters which he claws. He unrolls one parcel and goes to dump the crubeen softly but holds back and feels the trotter. He upturns his eyes. He urged me Stating that he felt it his mission in life to urge me. to defile the marriage bed, to commit adultery at the earliest possible opportunity. He urged me to do likewise, to misbehave, to sin with officers of the garrison. He’ve got the chink ad lib. He vividly recollected when the occurrence alluded to took place as well as yesterday, roughly some score of years previously in the days of the land troubles, when it took the civilised world by storm, figuratively speaking, early in the eighties, eightyone to be correct, when he was just turned fifteen. He voted for it and put on his topboots to ride to Dublin from the Ards of Down to do so. He wagged huge beard, huge face over his blunder huge. He wags his head with cackling raillery. He wailed: —And we to be there, mavrone, and you to be unbeknownst sending us your conglomerations the way we to have our tongues out a yard long like the drouthy clerics do be fainting for a pussful. He wails with the vehemence of the ocean. He waited by the counter, inhaling slowly the keen reek of drugs, the dusty dry smell of sponges and loofahs. He waited till she had laid the card aside and curled herself back slowly with a snug sigh. He waits to hear from me. He waits while you wait. He waits while you wait. He walked along the curbstone. He walked along the upwardcurving path. He walked back along Dorset street, reading gravely. He walked by the treeshade of sunnywinking leaves: and towards him came the wife of Mr David Sheehy M.P. —Very well, indeed, father. He walked calmly and read mutely the nones, walking and reading till he came to Res in Beati immaculati: Principium verborum tuorum veritas: in eternum omnia iudicia iustitiæ tuæ. He walked cheerfully towards the mosque of the baths. He walked jerkily into the office behind, parting the vent of his jacket, jingling his keys in his back pocket. He walked off quickly round the parapet. He walked on. He walked on. He walked on past Bolton’s Westmoreland house. He walked on, waiting to be spoken to, trailing his ashplant by his side. He walked southward along Westland row. He walked there, reading in the evening, and heard the cries of the boys’ lines at their play, young cries in the quiet evening. He walks. He walks, runs, zigzags, gallops, lugs laid back. He wandered back to the bar to the lost chord pipe. He wants it changed. —He wants it in for July, Mr Bloom said. He wants my money and my life, though want must be his master, for some brutish empire of his. He wants that key. He wants to go straight. He wants to see the files of the Kilkenny People for last year. He wants two keys at the top. —He wants you for the pressgang, J. J. O’Molloy said. He was. He was a crotchety old fellow in the primary stage of drink. He was a kind of sport gentleman that went for a merryandrew or honest pickle and what belonged of women, horseflesh or hot scandal he had it pat. He was all their daddies! He was alone. He was altogether too fagged out to institute a thorough search though he tried to recollect. —He was a rich country gentleman, Stephen said, with a coat of arms and landed estate at Stratford and a house in Ireland yard, a capitalist shareholder, a bill promoter, a tithefarmer. He was bloody safe he wasn’t run in himself under the act that time as a rogue and vagabond only he had a friend in court. He was but eleven months and nine days old and, though still a tiny toddler, was just beginning to lisp his first babyish words. He was chosen, it seems to me. He was down and out but, though branded as a black sheep, if he might say so, he meant to reform, to retrieve the memory of the past in a purely sisterly way and return to nature as a purely domestic animal. He was drummed out of the army. He was eying her as a snake eyes its prey. He was gone. He was himself a lord of language and had made himself a coistrel gentleman and he had written Romeo and Juliet. He was humane and honoured there. —He was in at lunchtime, miss Douce said. He was in deep mourning, she could see that, and the story of a haunting sorrow was written on his face. He was in John Henry Menton’s and then he went round to Collis and Ward’s and then Tom Rochford met him and sent him round to the subsheriff’s for a lark. He was in Mrs Cohen’s. He was in the bakery line too, wasn’t he? He was in the Red Bank this morning. He was, I understand, at one time a firstclass misdemeanant in Glencree reformatory. He was Judas Iacchia, a Libyan eunuch, the pope’s bastard. He was just a big nervous foolish noodly kind of a horse, without a second care in the world. He was laying his hand upon a winejar: Malachi saw it and withheld his act, pointing to the stranger and to the scarlet label. He was leaning back against the rock behind. He was looking up so intently, so still, and he saw her kick the ball and perhaps he could see the bright steel buckles of her shoes if she swung them like that thoughtfully with the toes down. —He was made in Germany, Stephen replied, as the champion French polisher of Italian scandals. He was neither as much as he would have liked to be either. He was not. He wasn’t in the chapel, that I’ll swear. He was on the Freeman once. He was out of a job and implored of Stephen to tell him where on God’s earth he could get something, anything at all, to do. He was overborne in a cornfield first ryefield, I should say and he will never be a victor in his own eyes after nor play victoriously the game of laugh and lie down. —He was raving all night about a black panther, Stephen said. He was simply and solely, as it subsequently transpired for reasons best known to himself, which put quite an altogether different complexion on the proceedings, after the moment before’s observations about boyhood days and the turf, recollecting two or three private transactions of his own which the other two were as mutually innocent of as the babe unborn. He was so kind and holy and often and often she thought and thought could she work a ruched teacosy with embroidered floral design for him as a present or a clock but they had a clock she noticed on the mantelpiece white and gold with a canarybird that came out of a little house to tell the time the day she went there about the flowers for the forty hours’ adoration because it was hard to know what sort of a present to give or perhaps an album of illuminated views of Dublin or some place. He was starving too though he hadn’t said a word about it. He was the croppy boy. He was the eldest son of inspector Corley of the G division, lately deceased, who had married a certain Katherine Brophy, the daughter of a Louth farmer. He was their rector: his reign was mild. He was the son of a noble and a bondwoman. He was too young to understand. He was walking by the hedge, reading, I think a brevier book with, I doubt not, a witty letter in it from Glycera or Chloe to keep the page. He watched her dodge through passers towards the shopfronts. He watched her pour into the measure and thence into the jug rich white milk, not hers. He watched the bristles shining wirily in the weak light as she tipped three times and licked lightly. He watched the dark eyeslits narrowing with greed till her eyes were green stones. He waves his hand. He wears a battered silk hat sideways on his head. He wears a dark mantle and drooping plumed sombrero. He wears a hairshirt of pure Irish manufacture winter and summer and scourges himself every Saturday. He wears a slate frockcoat with claret silk lapels, a gorget of cream tulle, a green lowcut waistcoat, stock collar with white kerchief, tight lavender trousers, patent pumps and canary gloves. He wears a white jersey on which an image of the Sacred Heart is stitched with the insignia of Garter and Thistle, Golden Fleece, Elephant of Denmark, Skinner’s and Probyn’s horse, Lincoln’s Inn bencher and ancient and honourable artillery company of Massachusetts. He wears dark velvet hose and silverbuckled pumps. He weeps tearlessly. He weighed the possible evidences for and against ritual murder: the incitations of the hierarchy, the superstition of the populace, the propagation of rumour in continued fraction of veridicity, the envy of opulence, the influence of retaliation, the sporadic reappearance of atavistic delinquency, the mitigating circumstances of fanaticism, hypnotic suggestion and somnambulism. He went. He went. He went in. He went in, bowing his head under the low lintel. He went into the inner office, closing the door behind him. He went on and down, mopping, chanting with waving graceful arms: —The most beautiful book that has come out of our country in my time. He went on by la maison Claire. He went out by the open porch and down the gravel path under the trees, hearing the cries of voices and crack of sticks from the playfield. He went out through the backdoor into the garden: stood to listen towards the next garden. He went over to it, held it in his hands awhile, feeling its coolness, smelling the clammy slaver of the lather in which the brush was stuck. He went through a form of clandestine marriage with at least one woman in the shadow of the Black church. He went to the desk near the window, pulled in his chair twice and read off some words from the sheet on the drum of his typewriter. He went to the door and, holding it ajar, paused. He went towards the window and, taking up the pettycash book, scanned its pages. He went very suddenly. He wheels Kitty into Lynch’s arms, snatches up his ashplant from the table and takes the floor. He wheels twins in a perambulator. He whirls round and round with dervish howls. He whispered then near Stephen’s ear: LENEHAN’S LIMERICK —There’s a ponderous pundit MacHugh Who wears goggles of ebony hue. He whispers. He whispers in the ear of a blushing waitress and laughs kindly. He whistles Don Giovanni, a cenar teco. He Who Himself begot middler the Holy Ghost and Himself sent Himself, Agenbuyer, between Himself and others, Who, put upon by His fiends, stripped and whipped, was nailed like bat to barndoor, starved on crosstree, Who let Him bury, stood up, harrowed hell, fared into heaven and there these nineteen hundred years sitteth on the right hand of His Own Self but yet shall come in the latter day to doom the quick and dead when all the quick shall be dead already. He will ask for it. —He will have it that Hamlet is a ghoststory, John Eglinton said for Mr Best’s behoof. He will never capture the Attic note. He will never forget the name, ever remember the night: first night, the bridenight. He will see in them grotesque attempts of nature to foretell or to repeat himself. He will surely remember. He winces. He winces. He winked. He winks at his audience. He wished that a tale of a deed should be told of a deed not by him should by him not be told. He withdrew his gaze after an instant. He withdrew his hand and pulled his dress to. He won’t give you any trouble, Bob. He won’t listen to me. He wore a long unsleeved garment of recently flayed oxhide reaching to the knees in a loose kilt and this was bound about his middle by a girdle of plaited straw and rushes. He wore a loose white silk neckcloth and altogether he looked though he was not a dying man. He wore a pair of gaiters the night that first we met. He worms down through a coalhole, his brown habit trailing its tether over rattling pebbles. He worries his butt. He would. He would and he wouldn’t, I suppose. He would be eleven now if he had lived. He would be tall with broad shoulders she had always admired tall men for a husband with glistening white teeth under his carefully trimmed sweeping moustache and they would go on the continent for their honeymoon three wonderful weeks! and then, when they settled down in a nice snug and cosy little homely house, every morning they would both have brekky, simple but perfectly served, for their own two selves and before he went out to business he would give his dear little wifey a good hearty hug and gaze for a moment deep down into her eyes. He would go to Buxton probably for the waters. —He would have been on the bench long ago, the professor said, only for .... He would have withdrawn from the feast had not the noise of voices allayed the smart. He would never have spoken with the Eternal amid lightnings on Sinai’s mountaintop nor ever have come down with the light of inspiration shining in his countenance and bearing in his arms the tables of the law, graven in the language of the outlaw. He would not believe in love, a woman’s birthright. He wouldn’t know what to do to. He wouldn’t surely? He wouldn’t take any money either. He wriggles. He wriggles forward and places an ear to the ground. He wrote me an anonymous letter in prentice backhand when my husband was in the North Riding of Tipperary on the Munster circuit, signed James Lovebirch. He wrote the play in the months that followed his father’s death. He wrote to me that he was miserable. Hey? He yawns, showing a coalblack throat, and closes his jaws by an upward push of his parchmentroll. Hhhhm. Hhhn: burst sideways. Hi! Hi! Hi! Hidden hand. Hidden under wild ferns on Howth below us bay sleeping: sky. Hide! Hide gold there. Hide her blushes. Hide my blushes someone. Hiesos Kristos, magician of the beautiful, the Logos who suffers in us at every moment. High, a high note pealed in the treble clear. High angle fire, inyah! High brown boots with laces dangling. Highclass licensed premises. High colour, of course. High falutin stuff. High grade. High jinks below stairs. Highly providential was the appearance on the scene of Corny Kelleher when Stephen was blissfully unconscious but for that man in the gap turning up at the eleventh hour the finis might have been that he might have been a candidate for the accident ward or, failing that, the bridewell and an appearance in the court next day before Mr Tobias or, he being the solicitor rather, old Wall, he meant to say, or Mahony which simply spelt ruin for a chap when it got bruited about. Highly respectable gondoliers! Highly unlikely of course there was even a shadow of truth in the stones and, even supposing, he thought a return highly inadvisable, all things considered. High on Ben Howth rhododendrons a nannygoat walking surefooted, dropping currants. High on Ben Howth through rhododendrons a nannygoat passes, plumpuddered, buttytailed, dropping currants. High School of Poula? High tea. High voices. High wall: beyond strings twanged. High water at Dublin bar. Hik! Hillyho! Him? Him? Him makee velly muchee fine night. Him Satan fleers, Mocker: And therefore he left out her name From the first draft but he did not leave out The presents for his granddaughter, for his daughters, For his sister, for his old cronies in Stratford And in London. —Himself his own father, Sonmulligan told himself. —Him, sir. Him, then Cranly, Mulligan: now these. Hippogriff. Hips. Hired dog! Hire only. Hire some old crock, safety. His advice to every Irishman was: stay in the land of your birth and work for Ireland and live for Ireland. His arm. His arm: Cranly’s arm. His articles on Shakespeare in the Saturday Review were surely brilliant. His art, more than the art of feudalism as Walt Whitman called it, is the art of surfeit. His attention was directed to them by his host jocosely, and he accepted them seriously as they drank in jocoserious silence Epps’s massproduct, the creature cocoa. His back is like that Norwegian captain’s. His back trouserbutton snaps. His bangle bracelets fall. His beaver is up. His Bloom’s logical conclusion, having weighed the matter and allowing for possible error? His blued feet out of turnedup trousers slapped the clammy sand, a dull brick muffler strangling his unshaven neck. His boots are spoiling the shape of my feet. His boots trod again a damp crackling mast, razorshells, squeaking pebbles, that on the unnumbered pebbles beats, wood sieved by the shipworm, lost Armada.
