Landlord never dies they say. Land of the setting sun this. Lang may your lum reek and your kailpot boil! Language no whit worse than his. Language of flowers. Language of love. Lank coils of seaweed hair around me, my heart, my soul. Lap it up like milk, I suppose. Lap, lapin. Lapwing. Lapwing. Lapwing. Lapwing be. Lapwing you are. Larches, firs, all the trees of the conifer family are going fast. La ree. LARRY O’ROURKE: An eightday licence for my new premises. L’art d’être grand... Lascivious people. Lashings of stuff we put up: port wine and sherry and curacoa to which we did ample justice. Lash under the belly with a knotted thong. Last act of Lucia. Last but not least. Last day! Last in a drizzle of rain on a brokenwinded isabelle nag, Cock of the North, the favourite, honey cap, green jacket, orange sleeves, Garrett Deasy up, gripping the reins, a hockeystick at the ready. Last lap. Last lap! Last look at mirror always before she answers the door. Lastly at the head of the board was the young poet who found a refuge from his labours of pedagogy and metaphysical inquisition in the convivial atmosphere of Socratic discussion, while to right and left of him were accommodated the flippant prognosticator, fresh from the hippodrome, and that vigilant wanderer, soiled by the dust of travel and combat and stained by the mire of an indelible dishonour, but from whose steadfast and constant heart no lure or peril or threat or degradation could ever efface the image of that voluptuous loveliness which the inspired pencil of Lafayette has limned for ages yet to come. Last night I flew. Last of his name and race. Last of my race. Last rose Castile of summer left bloom I feel so sad alone. Last time I saw him he had his heels on view. Last time I was here was Mrs Sinico’s funeral. Last tip to titivate. Last word in art shades. Last year travelling to Ennis had to pick up that farmer’s daughter’s bag and hand it to her at Limerick junction. Late lieabed under a quilt of old overcoats, fingering a pinchbeck bracelet, Dan Kelly’s token. LATE LORD MAYOR HARRINGTON: In scarlet robe with mace, gold mayoral chain and large white silk scarf. —Later on, Haines said. Later on please. Latin. Latin again. ........................ la tua pace .................. che parlar ti piace Mentre che il vento, come fa, si tace. Laud we the gods And let our crooked smokes climb to their nostrils From our bless’d altars. Laughing again, he brought the mirror away from Stephen’s peering eyes. Laughing, he... Laughing, linked, high haircombs flashing, they catch the sun in mocking mirrors, lifting their arms. Laughing witches in red cutty sarks ride through the air on broomsticks. Laughter. Laughter BUCKMULLIGAN: Piano, diminuendo Then outspoke medical Dick To his comrade medical Davy... Laughter in court. Laughter of men from the lane. Laughter QUAKERLYSTER: A tempo But he that filches from me my good name... Laughter seized all his strong wellknit trunk. Laur. Laurence Bloomfield in Ireland by William Allingham second edition, green cloth, gilt trefoil design, previous owner’s name on recto of flyleaf erased. À la vôtre! Lawksamercy, doctor, cried the young blood in the primrose vest, feigning a womanish simper and with immodest squirmings of his body, how you do tease a body! Lawn Tennyson, gentleman poet. Law of falling bodies: per second per second. Law, the classics... Lawyers of the past, haughty, pleading, beheld pass from the consolidated taxing office to Nisi Prius court Richie Goulding carrying the costbag of Goulding, Collis and Ward and heard rustling from the admiralty division of king’s bench to the court of appeal an elderly female with false teeth smiling incredulously and a black silk skirt of great amplitude. Laying it out. Lay it on with a trowel. Lay me in my native earth. Lay of the last minstrel he thought it was. Lay you two to one Jenatzy licks him ruddy well hollow. Lazy idle little schemer. Lazy idle little schemer. L. Bloom, who met with a mixed reception of applause and hisses, having espoused the negative the vocalist chairman brought the discussion to a close, in response to repeated requests and hearty plaudits from all parts of a bumper house, by a remarkably noteworthy rendering of the immortal Thomas Osborne Davis’ evergreen verses happily too familiar to need recalling here A nation once again in the execution of which the veteran patriot champion may be said without fear of contradiction to have fairly excelled himself. Là ci darem la mano. —Là ci darem with J. C. Doyle, she said, and Love’s Old Sweet Song. Lead him not into temptation. Leading a quadruple existence! Leading him the life of the damned. Leah tonight. Lean, he lay back. Leaning on it he looked down on the water and on the mailboat clearing the harbourmouth of Kingstown. Leanjawed harpy, hard woman at a bargain, her bonnet awry. Lean on me. Lean people long mouths. Learn a lot teaching others. Learn anything if taken young. Learned when I served my time and worked the mail order line for Kellett’s. Learn German too. Learn the smooth mincing walk on four inch Louis Quinze heels, the Grecian bend with provoking croup, the thighs fluescent, knees modestly kissing. Leather. Leave her: get tired. Leave him to me. Leave him under an obligation: costs nothing. Leave the court immediately, sir. Leave ye fraction of bread to them that live by bread alone. Leaving the door ajar, amid the stench of mouldy limewash and stale cobwebs he undid his braces. Le distrait or absentminded beggar. Led on by the smell or the look. Leeolee! Leering, Gerty Macdowell limps forward. Leftherhis Secondbest Leftherhis Bestabed Secabest Leftabed. Left him weeping, I suppose? Left one is more sensitive, I think. Leg bail. Leg before wicket. Leg it, ye devils! Lei rovina tutto. Lemons it is. Lemur, who are you? Lend him to me. Lend us one. LENEHAN: A good night’s work. Lenehan and Mr O’Madden Burke, hearing, turned, beckoned and led on across towards Mooney’s. Lenehan announced gladly: —The Rose of Castile. Lenehan began to paw the tissues up from the floor, grunting as he stooped twice. Lenehan bowed to a shape of air, announcing: —Madam, I’m Adam. Lenehan came forward. Lenehan cried. Lenehan cried, running to the window. Lenehan extended his hands in protest. Lenehan gave a loud cough. Lenehan gets some good ones. Lenehan gulped to go. Lenehan heard and knew and hailed him: —See the conquering hero comes. LENEHAN: Ho! Lenehan in yachtsman’s cap and white shoes officiously detaches a long hair from Blazes Boylan’s coat shoulder. Lenehan laughed. Lenehan, lighting it for him with quick grace, said: —Silence for my brandnew riddle! Lenehan linked his arm warmly. Lenehan lit their cigarettes as before and took his trophy, saying: —Muchibus thankibus. Lenehan opened most genial arms. LENEHAN: Plagiarist! Lenehan promptly struck a match for them and lit their cigarettes in turn. Lenehan, rising to tiptoe, fanned his face rapidly with the rustling tissues. Lenehan round the sandwichbell wound his round body round. Lenehan said. Lenehan said. Lenehan said to all: —Silence! Lenehan’s lips over the counter lisped a low whistle of decoy. Lenehan, small eyes ahunger on her humming, bust ahumming, tugged Blazes Boylan’s elbowsleeve. LENEHAN: Smells gleefully. Lenehan still drank and grinned at his tilted ale and at miss Douce’s lips that all but hummed, not shut, the oceansong her lips had trilled. Lenehan stopped and leaned on the riverwall, panting with soft laughter. Lenehan’s yachting cap on the cadge beyond. Lenehan walked on again. Lenehan wept with a little noise. LENEHAN: What about mixed bathing? Lent it to his friend. Leo! Leopardstown. Leopold. Leopold! Leopold Bloom aged 6 had accompanied these narrations by constant consultation of a geographical map of Europe political and by suggestions for the establishment of affiliated business premises in the various centres mentioned. Leopold Bloom Ellpodbomool Molldopeloob Bollopedoom Old Ollebo, M. P. What acrostic upon the abbreviation of his first name had he kinetic poet sent to Miss Marion Molly Tweedy on the 14 February 1888? Leopold Bloom for it is he stands silent, with bowed head before those young guileless eyes. Leopold cut liverslices. Leopoldi autem generatio. —Leopoldo or the Bloom is on the Rye, Lenehan said. Leopold, Patrick, Andrew, David, George, be thou anointed! Leopold, yes. Leopopold! Les jeux sont faits! Les petites femmes. Les ponts! Les ronds! Less than he had imagined, more than he had hoped. Lesurques and Dubosc. Let everything rip. Let Gumley mind the stones, see they don’t run away. Lethal chamber. Lethargy. Lethargy then. Let her pass. Let her speak. Let her wait. Let him. Let him be taken, Mr Subsheriff, from the dock where he now stands and detained in custody in Mountjoy prison during His Majesty’s pleasure and there be hanged by the neck until he is dead and therein fail not at your peril or may the Lord have mercy on your soul. Let him give us a three months’ renewal. —Let him in. —Let him! she said with a pert toss of her head and a piquant tilt of her nose. —Let him stay, Stephen said. Let Him take me whenever He likes. Let him take that in first. Let it go. Let me. Let me. —Let me alone, says he. Let me be and let me live. Let me be going now, woman of the house, for by all the goats in Connemara I’m after having the father and mother of a bating. Let me be the first to. —Let me cross your bows mate, he said to his neighbour who was just gently dropping off into a peaceful doze. Let me go. Let me off this once. Let me on him now. Let me parturiate! —Let me, said he, so far presume upon our acquaintance which, however slight it may appear if judged by the standard of mere time, is founded, as I hope and believe, on a sentiment of mutual esteem as to request of you this favour. Let me say one thing. Let me see. Let me see. Let me see. Let me see. Let me see now. Let me stir it. Let me there. Let me think. Let my epitaph be. Let off steam. Let out to graze. Let people get fond of each other: lure them on. —Let’s hear the time, he said. Let’s ring all the bells in Montague street. Let Stephen in. Letter. Letter? Letter from His Grace. Letter I have. Letters on his back: I.N.R.I? Letters read out for breach of promise. Let the lewd with faith and fervour worship. Let them all come. Let them all go to pot. Let them go and fight the Boers! Let them hymn it nine times nine. Let them sleep in their maggoty beds. Let there be life. Let this man pass. Letting the blind up by gentle tugs halfway his backward eye saw her glance at the letter and tuck it under her pillow. Lettuce. Let us build an altar to Jehovah. Let us change the subject. Let us construct a watercloset. Let us drink our pints in peace. Let us get out of the kip. Let us go. —Let us go round by the chief’s grave, Hynes said. Let us hear what you have to say of Richard and Edmund. LET US HOPE J. J. O’Molloy, about to follow him in, said quietly to Stephen: —I hope you will live to see it published. —Let us, Mr Power said. Let us see. Let us sit down somewhere and discuss. Levanted with the cash of a few ads. Leverage, see? Lewd chimpanzee. Lewdly. L’homme primigène! L’homme qui rit! Liar! —Libel action, says he, for ten thousand pounds. Liberty and exaltation of our holy mother the church. Library. Licensed for the sale of beer, wine and spirits for consumption on the premises. Licentious men. Li Chi Han lovey up kissy Cha Pu Chow. Licking pennies. Lick it off the plate, man! Lick it up smokinghot, thick sugary. Lid Ker Cow De and Doll. Lids of Juno’s eyes, violets. Lidwell. Lidwell asked. Lie. Lies. Lieutenant Myers of the Dublin Fire Brigade by general request sets fire to Bloom. Life a dream for him. Life and Miracles of the Curé of Ars. Life is many days. Life is too short. Life, life. Life, love, voyage round your own little world. Life might be so. Life of life, thy lips enkindle. LIFE ON THE RAW —They buy one and fourpenceworth of brawn and four slices of panloaf at the north city diningrooms in Marlborough street from Miss Kate Collins, proprietress... Life’s dream is o’er. Life those chaps out there must have, stuck in the same spot. Life with hard labour. Lifted. Lighted Candle in Stick borne by BLOOM Diaconal Hat on Ashplant borne by STEPHEN With what intonation secreto of what commemorative psalm? Lighten up at the last moment and recognise for the last time. Lighthearted deceiver and fickle like all his sex he would never understand what he had meant to her and for an instant there was in the blue eyes a quick stinging of tears. Light in his eyes. Light is a kind of reassuring. Light, life and love, by God. Lightly he played a light bright tinkling measure for tripping ladies, arch and smiling, and for their gallants, gentlemen friends. Lights! Light sob of breath Bloom sighed on the silent bluehued flowers. Light swift her eyes kindled, bloom of blushes his word winning. Light they want. Light too. Light to the gentiles. Like a cat sitting beyond a dog’s jump. Like a child’s hand, his hand. Like actresses, always farewell positively last performance then come up smiling again. Like a few olives too if they had them. Like a hero. Like a little man in a cloak he is with tiny hands. Like a man walking in his sleep. Like a mortuary chapel. Like Cashel Boylo Connoro Coylo Tisdall Maurice Tisntdall Farrell. Liked me or what? Like down a coalshoot. Like dying in sleep. —Like fellows who had blown up the Bastile, J. J. O’Molloy said in quiet mockery. Like flowers. Like foul flowerwater. Like getting £. s. d. out of him. Like him was I, these sloping shoulders, this gracelessness. Like holding water in your hand. Like John o’Gaunt his name is dear to him, as dear as the coat and crest he toadied for, on a bend sable a spear or steeled argent, honorificabilitudinitatibus, dearer than his glory of greatest shakescene in the country. Like kids your second visit to a house. Like lady, ladylike. Like Mary, queen of Scots, something. Like me, like Algy, coming down to our mighty mother. Like Milly’s was. Like Molly. Like mouthfuls of strawberries and cream. Like old times. Like ole Billyo. Like our small talk. Like pickled pork. Like princes, faith. Like Shakespeare’s face. Like sir Philip Crampton’s fountain. Like stuffed. Like tearing silk. Like that. Like that. Like that. Like that. Like that haughty creature at the polo match. Like that, heavy, sweet, wild perfume. —Like that, Mr Bloom said, crossing his forefingers at the top. Like that Peter or Denis or James Carey that blew the gaff on the invincibles. Like that priest they are this morning: we have sinned: we have suffered. Like that something. Like the fat boy in Pickwick he wants to make our flesh creep. Like these, got out of hand: fermenting. Like the way it curves there. Like the wedding present alderman Hooper gave us. Like those bubblyjocular Roman matrons one reads of in Elephantuliasis. Like those rhapsodies of Liszt’s, Hungarian, gipsyeyed. Like through a colander. Like to answer them all. Like to be that rock she sat on. Like to give them an odd cigarette. Like to see her again in that. Like to see them sitting round in a ring with blub lips, entranced, listening. Like what? Like women they like rencontres. Like you men. Lil chile velly solly. Liliata rutilantium. Liliata rutilantium. Liliata rutilantium te confessorum turma circumdet: iubilantium te virginum chorus excipiat. Li li poo lil chile Blingee pigfoot evly night Payee two shilly... Lily of the alley. Limit of the diaphane in. Limits of the diaphane. Lineaments of gratified desire. Line of fate. Lines in her eyes. Lines round her mouth. Lingerie does it. LINKS WITH BYGONE DAYS OF YORE —Grattan and Flood wrote for this very paper, the editor cried in his face. Lionel Simon, singer, laughed. Lionel’s song. Lionel, thou lost one! Lip blow. Lipoti Virag, basilicogrammate, chutes rapidly down through the chimneyflue and struts two steps to the left on gawky pink stilts. Lips kissed, kissing, kissed. Lips laughing. —Liquids I can eat, Stephen said. Liquor, what? Lir’s loneliest daughter. List! List! Listen. Listen. Listen. Listen! Listen. Listen. Listen: a fourworded wavespeech: seesoo, hrss, rsseeiss, ooos. Listener: reclined semilaterally, left, left hand under head, right leg extended in a straight line and resting on left leg, flexed, in the attitude of Gea-Tellus, fulfilled, recumbent, big with seed. Listener, S. E. by E.: Narrator, N. W. by W.: on the 53rd parallel of latitude, N., and 6th meridian of longitude, W.: at an angle of 45° to the terrestrial equator. Listening, he heard her voice: —Come, come, pussy. —Listen! she bade him. Listen: the man. Listen to the births and deaths in the Irish all for Ireland Independent, and I’ll thank you and the marriages. Listen to this, will you? List, list, O list! Liszt’s rhapsodies. Literally astounded at this piece of intelligence Bloom reflected. —Literature, the press. Litigation. Little. Little Alf Bergan, cloaked in the pall of the ace of spades, dogs him to left and right, doubled in laughter. Little Alf Bergan popped in round the door and hid behind Barney’s snug, squeezed up with the laughing. Little Alf was knocked bawways. Little dog, die. Little father! Little hand it was: now big. Little Harry Hughes and his schoolfellows all Went out for to play ball. Little jobs that make mother pleased, eh? Little monkeys common as ditchwater. Little paps to begin with. Little piece of steel iron. Little recked he perhaps for what she felt, that dull aching void in her heart sometimes, piercing to the core. Little sweetheart come and kiss me. Little wind piped wee. Live axle drives are souped. Live by their wits. Live for ever practically. Live on fish, fishy flesh they have, all seabirds, gulls, seagoose. Liver and bacon. Liver and kidney. Liverpool boat long gone. Liverpool ring which jockeyed the Galway harbour scheme. Live us again. Living all the day among herbs, ointments, disinfectants. Living in a bogswamp, eating cheap food and the streets paved with dust, horsedung and consumptives’ spits. Living on the fat of the land. Living to spite them. L. J. Hickey, O. P.; the very rev. —’lldo! cried Father Cowley. —L, Mr Bloom said. Lo! Loam, what is this that is? Loans by post on easy terms. Lobbing about waiting for him. Lobster and mayonnaise. Lobsters boiled alive. Local colour. Lockhart’s Life of Napoleon cover wanting, marginal annotations, minimising victories, aggrandising defeats of the protagonist. Lockjaw. Locks and keys! Locomotor ataxy. —Lo, Joe, says I. Lo, levin leaping lightens in eyeblink Ireland’s westward welkin. Lollipop. London? London’s burning, London’s burning! London’s teapot and I’m simply teapot all over me! —Long ago? Long ago I was a king Now I do this kind of thing On the wing, on the wing! Long and the short of it. Long cold upper lip. Long day I’ve had. Longer in dying call. Longest way round is the shortest way home. Longfelt want. LONGHAND AND SHORTHAND: Without looking up from their notebooks. Longindying call. Longing to get the fright of their lives. Long in the tooth and superfluous hair. Long John. Long John. Long John Fanning blew a plume of smoke from his lips. Long John Fanning could not remember him. Long John Fanning made no way for them. LONG JOHN FANNING: Scowls and calls with rich rolling utterance. Long John is backing him, they say. Long live life! Long long long rest. Long, short and long. —Longworth and M’Curdy Atkinson were there... —Longworth is awfully sick, he said, after what you wrote about that old hake Gregory. Longworth will give it a good puff in the Express. Look. Look... Look! Look at all the things they can learn to do. Look at Bantam’s flowers. Look at here. Look at here. —Look at here, he said turning. Look at him. —Look at him, says he. Look at his head. Look at his mouth. Look at it other way round. Look at me. —Look at that now, she said. Look at the holy show I am. Look at them. Look at the woebegone walk of him. —Look at the young guttersnipe behind him hue and cry, Lenehan said, and you’ll kick. Look at the young scamps after him. Look at this long candle. Look at this, says he. Look at what I’m standing drinks to! —Look at yourself, he said, you dreadful bard! Look clock. Look down at her ring to find an excuse. Looked?... Looked enough. Looked round. Looked shut. Look for something I. Look forth now, my people, upon the land of behest, even from Horeb and from Nebo and from Pisgah and from the Horns of Hatten unto a land flowing with milk and money. Look here. —Look here, Martin, John Wyse Nolan said, overtaking them at the Mail office. Looking at me, the sheet up to her eyes, Spanish, smelling herself, when I was fixing the links in my cuffs. Looking at the tips of her hairs to see if they are split. Looking away now. Looking back now in a retrospective kind of arrangement all seemed a kind of dream. Looking down he saw flapping strongly, wheeling between the gaunt quaywalls, gulls. Looking for grub. Looking for something lost in a past life. Looking for trouble. Looking from Buena Vista. Looking out over the sea she told me. Looking up again he set them free. Looking up from the back garden. Look in here. Look: look, look, look, look, look: you look at us. Look on this picture then on that. Look out. Look out for squalls. Looks a fright in the day. Looks as good as new now. Looks as if they did it for a bet. Looks full up of bad gas. Look sharp and you’ll catch him. Looks horrid open. Looks like a phantom ship. Look slippery. Looks mangled out: had a good tuck in. Looks she too not other now? Looks so forlorn. Look straight in her eyes. Look, there’s all I have. Look to our steeds. Look to the west. Look under the bed for what’s not there. Loosen his boots. Loose sand and shellgrit crusted her bare feet. Loose tobaccoshreds catch fire: a flame and acrid smoke light our corner. Lord! Lord! Lord! Lord Howard de Walden’s. Lord Howard de Walden’s Zinfandel M. Cannon 2. Lord, I am wet. Lord, I mustn’t lilt here. Lord, is he going to attack me? Lord Iveagh once cashed a sevenfigure cheque for a million in the bank of Ireland. Lord Jesus? Lord John Corley some called him and his genealogy came about in this wise. Lord knows what concoction. Lord knows where they are gone. Lord lieutenant. —Lord love a duck, he said. Lord mayor had his eye on her too. Lord mayor of Dublin! Lord Salisbury? Lord, she must have looked a sight that night Dedalus told me he was in there. Lord Talbot de Malahide, immediate hereditary lord admiral of Malahide and the seas adjoining. LORD TENNYSON: Gentleman poet in Union Jack blazer and cricket flannels, bareheaded, flowingbearded. Lord, they are weary; and, whispered to, they sigh. Lose it out of that pocket. Lose your customers that way. Losing heart. Lost. LOST CAUSES NOBLE MARQUESS MENTIONED —We were always loyal to lost causes, the professor said. Lost her husband. Lost it. Loth to irk in Horne’s hall hat holding the seeker stood. Lot of babies she must have helped into the world. Lot of ground he must cover in the day. Lot of thanks I get. Lot of time taken up telling your aches and pains. Lots must be killed in storms, telegraph wires. Lots of them like that at this moment all over the world. Lots of them lying around here: lungs, hearts, livers. Lotty Clarke, flaxenhaired, I saw at her night toilette through illclosed curtains with poor papa’s operaglasses: The wanton ate grass wildly. Lotus ladies tend them i’the eyes, their pineal glands aglow. Loud. Loudly. Loud on left Thor thundered: in anger awful the hammerhurler. Lou heap good man. Louis H. Victory. —Louis Werner is touring her, Mr Bloom said. Lourdes cure, waters of oblivion, and the Knock apparition, statues bleeding. —Love! Love. Love among the tombstones. Love and laud him: me no more. —Love and War, Ben, Mr Dedalus said. Love and War someone is. Loved to count my waistcoat buttons. Love entanglement. Love is the name? Love laughs at locksmiths. Loveless, landless, wifeless. Love, lie and be handsome for tomorrow we die. Love loves to love love. —Lovely! Lovely! Lovely. Lovely air. Lovely forms of women sculped Junonian. Lovely maidens sit in close proximity to the roots of the lovely trees singing the most lovely songs while they play with all kinds of lovely objects as for example golden ingots, silvery fishes, crans of herrings, drafts of eels, codlings, creels of fingerlings, purple seagems and playful insects. Lovely name you have. Lovely seaside girls. Lovely shame. Lovely spot it must be: the garden of the world, big lazy leaves to float about on, cactuses, flowery meads, snaky lianas they call them. —Lovely weather, sir. Lovely weather we’re having. Lovemaking damages. Lovemaking in Irish, £ 200 damages. Love me. Love me not. Love, moya! Love one another. Love or burgundy. Love or money. Lovephiltres. Lover, for her love he prowled with colonel Richard Burke, tanist of his sept, under the walls of Clerkenwell and, crouching, saw a flame of vengeance hurl them upward in the fog. Lover of an ideal or a perversion, like José he kills the real Carmen. Lovers: yum yum. —Love, says Bloom. Love’s bitter mystery. Love’s old sweet song. Love’s old sweet song. Love’s Old Sweet Song Comes lo-ove’s old... Love’s old sweet sonnez la gold. Love that dare not speak its name. Love that is singing: love’s old sweet song. Love, yes. Lovey lovekin. Love your neighbour. Low. Low blackguardism! Low in dark middle earth. Low sank the music, air and words. Loyal to a lost cause. Loyal to the highest constituted power in the land, actuated by an innate love of rectitude his aims would be the strict maintenance of public order, the repression of many abuses though not of all simultaneously every measure of reform or retrenchment being a preliminary solution to be contained by fluxion in the final solution, the upholding of the letter of the law common, statute and law merchant against all traversers in covin and trespassers acting in contravention of bylaws and regulations, all resuscitators by trespass and petty larceny of kindlings of venville rights, obsolete by desuetude, all orotund instigators of international persecution, all perpetuators of international animosities, all menial molestors of domestic conviviality, all recalcitrant violators of domestic connubiality. Lozenge and comfit manufacturer to His Majesty the King. Lub! Lubber... Lubricate. Lucky I had the presence of mind to dive into Manning’s or I was souped. Lucky it didn’t. Lucky Molly got over hers lightly. Lucky no woman. Ludamassy! Lugugugubrious. Lui, c’est moi. Lukewarm glue in Thom’s next door when I was there. Lukewarm water...? Lullaby. Lulls all pain. Lumpmusic. Lump of love. Luncheon interval. Luring. Lycopodium. Lydia, admired, admired. LYDIA DOUCE: Her mouth opening. Lydia for Lidwell squeak scarcely hear so ladylike the muse unsqueaked a ray of hopk. Lying out on the strand all day. Lying up in the hotel Pisser was telling me once a month with headache like a totty with her courses. Lynch! LYNCH: Across the world for a wife. LYNCH: All one and the same God to her. Lynch and Kitty and Zoe stampede from the room. Lynch, a Scots fellow, Will. LYNCH: Ba! Lynch bends Kitty back over the sofa and kisses her. LYNCH: Calls from the hearth. LYNCH: Damn your yellow stick. LYNCH: Deeply. Lynch, did I show you the letter about the lute? LYNCH: Embracing Kitty on the sofa, chants deeply. Lynch gets up, rights his cap and, clasping Kitty’s waist, adds his head to the group. LYNCH: Handing her coins. LYNCH: He is. LYNCH: He likes dialectic, the universal language. Lynch, his jockeycap low on his brow, attends him, a sneer of discontent wrinkling his face. LYNCH: Hoopla! LYNCH: I hope you gave the good father a penance. LYNCH: I’m not looking ZOE: Makes sheep’s eyes. Lynch indicates mockingly the couple at the piano. LYNCH: Laughing, slaps Kitty behind twice. LYNCH: Laughs. LYNCH: Let him alone. LYNCH: Lifting Kitty from the table. Lynch lifts the curled catterpillar on his wand. Lynch lifts up her skirt and white petticoat with the wand. LYNCH: Points. LYNCH: Pommelling on the sofa. LYNCH: Pornosophical philotheology. Lynch puts on her hat. LYNCH: Rushes forward and seizes Stephen’s hand. Lynch scares it with a kick. LYNCH: Sheet lightning courage. LYNCH: So that? Lynch squats crosslegged on the hearthrug of matted hair, his cap back to the front. LYNCH: Three wise virgins. Lynch tosses a cigarette from the sofa to the table. LYNCH: Tossing a cigarette on to the table. LYNCH: Vive le vampire! LYNCH: Watching him. LYNCH: Which is the jug of bread? LYNCH: With a mocking whinny of laughter grins at Bloom and Zoe Higgins. Lynch with his poker lifts boldly a side of her slip. Lynx eye. LYSTER: In quakergrey kneebreeches and broadbrimmed hat, says discreetly. Lyum! —Ma! Ma! —Ma ascolta! Maas was the boy. Machines. Machines is their cry, their chimera, their panacea. Machree, macruiskeen. —Macintosh. Mackerel they called me. Mac Somebody. Madame: smiling. Madam, excuse me. Madam Tweedy is in her bath, sir. Madam, when we last had this pleasure by letter dated the sixteenth instant... Madcap Ciss with her golliwog curls. Madden back Madden’s a maddening back. Madden had lost five drachmas on Sceptre for a whim of the rider’s name: Lenehan as much more. Madden, T. Lenehan, very sad about a racer he fancied and Stephen D. Leop. Made a big deal on Coates’s shares. Made him feel a bit peckish. Made me feel so young. Made me laugh to see. Made up for that tramdriver this morning. Mad Fanny and his other sister Mrs Dickinson driving about with scarlet harness. Ma, dia retta a me. Mad romp that she is, she had pulled her fill as we reclined together. Maeterlinck says: If Socrates leave his house today he will find the sage seated on his doorstep. Magdalen asylum. MAGEEGLINJOHN: Names! Magennis thinks you must have been pulling A. E.’s leg. Maggy at the range rammed down a greyish mass beneath bubbling suds twice with her potstick and wiped her brow. Maggy poured yellow thick soup from the kettle into a bowl. Maggy, pouring yellow soup in Katey’s bowl, exclaimed: —Boody! MAGINNI: Avant huit! MAGINNI: Boulangère! MAGINNI: Clipclaps glovesilent hands. MAGINNI: Dansez avec vos dames! MAGINNI: The poetry of motion, art of calisthenics. Magmagnificence! Magnetic needle tells you what’s going on in the sun, the stars. M. A. Hackett, C. C.; the rev. Mahak makar a bak. Mahar shalal hashbaz. Maiden discovered with pensive bosom. Maidenhead inside. Mailboat. Mais bien sûr, noble stranger, said he cheerily, et mille compliments. Mais nom de nom, that is another pair of trousers. Major Tweedy and the Citizen exhibit to each other medals, decorations, trophies of war, wounds. MAJOR TWEEDY: Growls gruffly. MAJOR TWEEDY: Loudly. Major Tweedy, moustached like Turko the terrible, in bearskin cap with hackleplume and accoutrements, with epaulettes, gilt chevrons and sabretaches, his breast bright with medals, toes the line. Make a bleeding butcher’s shop of the bugger. Make a detour. Make a picnic of it. Make a stump speech out of it. Make a summerhouse here. Make hay while the sun shines. Make her hear. Make him independent. Make him smart, Hanna dear. Make it up, please. Make room in the bed. Makes it more aristocratic than for example if he drank what they are used to Guinness’s porter or some temperance beverage Wheatley’s Dublin hop bitters or Cantrell and Cochrane’s ginger ale aromatic. Makes them feel more important to be prayed over in Latin. Makes you feel young. Makes you want to sing after. Make their own use of everything. Make them accomplices. Make themselves thoroughly at home. Make you buy what he wants to sell. Making for the museum gate with long windy steps he lifted his eyes. Making his day’s stations, the dingy printingcase, his three taverns, the Montmartre lair he sleeps short night in, rue de la Goutte-d’Or, damascened with flyblown faces of the gone. Making his rounds. Malachias, overcome by emotion, ceased. Malachi Mulligan is coming too. Malachi Mulligan, The Ship, lower Abbey street. Maledicity! he exclaimed in anguish. Male impersonator. Malign such an one, the amiable Miss Callan, who is the lustre of her own sex and the astonishment of ours? —Mallarmé, don’t you know, he said, has written those wonderful prose poems Stephen MacKenna used to read to me in Paris. —Malt for Richie and Stephen, tell mother. Mamma! Mamma! Mamma, poor mamma, and little Rudy. Mammoth roses murmur of scarlet winegrapes. Ma mère m’a mariée. Man all tattered and torn that married a maiden all forlorn. MANANAUN MACLIR: With a voice of waves. Man and woman, love, what is it? —Man delights him not nor woman neither, Stephen said. Mangy ravenous brute sniffing and sneezing all round the place and scratching his scabs. Mankind is incorrigible. Man loves her yoni fiercely with big lingam, the stiff one. Manna. Manner of Oxenford. Man, now fierce angry, strikes woman’s fat yadgana. Man’s head found in a garden. Mansmell, I mean. Mantailored with selfcovered buttons. Mantamer! Manufactured by George Plumtree, 23 Merchants’ quay, Dublin, put up in 4 oz pots, and inserted by Councillor Joseph P. Nannetti, M. P., Rotunda Ward, 19 Hardwicke street, under the obituary notices and anniversaries of deceases. Manx cat! Many. —Many a good man’s fault, Mr Dedalus said with a sigh. Many a good one he told himself. Many a time and oft were they wont to come there to that favourite nook to have a cosy chat beside the sparkling waves and discuss matters feminine, Cissy Caffrey and Edy Boardman with the baby in the pushcar and Tommy and Jacky Caffrey, two little curlyheaded boys, dressed in sailor suits with caps to match and the name H. M. S. Belleisle printed on both. Many bonafide travellers and ownerless dogs come near him and defile him. Many errors, many failures but not the one sin. Many have found him a dear man, a dear person. Many most attractive and enthusiastic women also commit suicide by stabbing, drowning, drinking prussic acid, aconite, arsenic, opening their veins, refusing food, casting themselves under steamrollers, from the top of Nelson’s Pillar, into the great vat of Guinness’s brewery, asphyxiating themselves by placing their heads in gasovens, hanging themselves in stylish garters, leaping from windows of different storeys. M. A. P. Mainly all pictures. —M’appari, Simon, Father Cowley said. Marble could give the original, shoulders, back, all the symmetry, all the rest. March! Mare on form hot order. —Marina, Stephen said, a child of storm, Miranda, a wonder, Perdita, that which was lost. Marion. Marion... MARION: He ought to feel himself highly honoured. MARION: Let him look, the pishogue! MARION: Nebrakada! MARION: Softly. MARION: So you notice some change? MARION’S VOICE: Hoarsely, sweetly, rising to her throat. MARION: Ti trema un poco il cuore? MARION: Welly? Mark for a softnosed bullet. Mark me now. —Mark my words, Mr Dedalus, he said. Mark of the beast. Mark this farther and remember. Mark time. Marriage ads they never try to beautify. Married. Married. Married, I see. Married to Bloom, to greaseabloom. Married too. —Married to the greasy nose! she yelled. Marry in May and repent in December. Marry, I wanted it. Marshall’s dark horse Sir Hugo captured the blue ribband at long odds. Martello you call it? Martha! —Martha! Martha and Mary will be a little chilly at first in such delicate thighcasing but the frilly flimsiness of lace round your bare knees will remind you... Martha, chestnote, return! Martha it is. Martha, Mary. Martha, she. MARTHA: Sobbing behind her veil. Martha, the bath, funeral, house of Keyes, museum with those goddesses, Dedalus’ song. MARTHA: Thickveiled, a crimson halter round her neck, a copy of the Irish Times in her hand, in tone of reproach, pointing. Martin asked me to go to the house. Martin could wind a sappyhead like that round his little finger, without his seeing it. Martin Cunningham asked. Martin Cunningham asked. Martin Cunningham asked, as they went on up the staircase. Martin Cunningham asked, twirling the peak of his beard gently. Martin Cunningham began to brush away crustcrumbs from under his thighs. Martin Cunningham could work a pass for the Gaiety. Martin Cunningham cried. Martin Cunningham drew out his watch briskly, coughed and put it back. Martin Cunningham emerged from a sidepath, talking gravely. [ 6 ] Martin Cunningham, first, poked his silkhatted head into the creaking carriage and, entering deftly, seated himself. Martin Cunningham forgot to give us his spellingbee conundrum this morning. Martin Cunningham frequently said he would work a pass through Egan but some deuced hitch or other eternally cropped up with the net result that the scheme fell through. MARTIN CUNNINGHAM: Gazes on her, impassive. Martin Cunningham in bed, Jack Power in bed, Simon Dedalus in bed, Ned Lambert in bed, Tom Kernan in bed, Joe Hynes in bed, John Henry Menton in bed, Bernard Corrigan in bed, Patsy Dignam in bed, Paddy Dignam in the grave. Martin Cunningham nudged Mr Power. Martin Cunningham put out his arm and, wrenching back the handle, shoved the door open with his knee. Martin Cunningham said. Martin Cunningham said. Martin Cunningham said piously. Martin Cunningham said, raising his palm to his brow in salute. Martin Cunningham said shortly. Martin Cunningham’s large eyes. Martin Cunningham, speaking always, showed often the list at which Jimmy Henry did not glance. Martin Cunningham spoke by turns, twirling the peak of his beard, to the assistant town clerk and the subsheriff, while John Wyse Nolan held his peace. Martin Cunningham thwarted his speech rudely: —Reuben J and the son were piking it down the quay next the river on their way to the Isle of Man boat and the young chiseller suddenly got loose and over the wall with him into the Liffey. Martin Cunningham twirled more quickly the peak of his beard. Martin Cunningham whispered: —I was in mortal agony with you talking of suicide before Bloom. —Martin is going to get up a whip for the youngsters, Ned Lambert said, pointing ahead. Martin is trying to get the youngster into Artane. Martin laying down the law. Mary Anderson is up there now. Mary Driscoll, a slipshod servant girl, approaches. MARY DRISCOLL: Excitedly. MARY DRISCOLL: He made a certain suggestion but I thought more of myself as poor as I am. MARY DRISCOLL: He surprised me in the rere of the premises, Your honour, when the missus was out shopping one morning with a request for a safety pin. MARY DRISCOLL: Indignantly. MARY DRISCOLL: Scornfully. Mary, Martha. Mason, I think: not sure. Massage. Massboy. Massed bands blare Garryowen and God save the King. Masses for the repose of my soul to be said publicly with open doors. Mass seems to be over. Master! Master Brunny Lynam ran across the road and put Father Conmee’s letter to father provincial into the mouth of the bright red letterbox. Master Dignam got his collar down and dawdled on. Master Dignam on his left turned as he turned. Master Dignam walked along Nassau street, shifted the porksteaks to his other hand. Mastering his troubled breath, he said: —I’ll take this one. Master Lenehan at this made return that he had heard of those nefarious deeds and how, as he heard hereof counted, he had besmirched the lily virtue of a confiding female which was corruption of minors and they all intershowed it too, waxing merry and toasting to his fathership. Masterly rendition. Master Patrick Aloysius Dignam came out of Mangan’s, late Fehrenbach’s, carrying a pound and a half of porksteaks. Mastiansky and Citron approach in gaberdines, wearing long earlocks. MASTIANSKY AND CITRON: Belial! —Ma, sul serio, eh? Matcham often thinks of the masterstroke. Matcham often thinks of the masterstroke by which he won the laughing witch who now. Matcham often thinks the laughing witch. Mat Dillon and his bevy of daughters: Tiny, Atty, Floey, Maimy, Louy, Hetty. Mat Dillon’s long ago. Material domination. Matter of fact I was just visiting an old friend of mine there, Virag, you don’t know him poor fellow, he’s laid up for the past week and we had a liquor together and I was just making my way home... Maud Gonne, beautiful woman, La Patrie, M. Millevoye, Félix Faure, know how he died? Maud Gonne’s letter about taking them off O’Connell street at night: disgrace to our Irish capital. Maul her a bit. Maunder on for hours, talking to himself or the other fellow blowing the bellows. Mawkish pulp her mouth had mumbled sweetsour of her spittle. Maximilian Karl O’Donnell, graf von Tirconnell in Ireland. Maximum the second. May Allah the Excellent One your soul this night ever tremendously conserve. May as well get her sympathy. May be for months and may be for never. Maybe he understands what I. Maybe, like Socrates, he had a midwife to mother as he had a shrew to wife. Maybe now. —Maybe so, says Joe. Maybe the women’s fault also. Mayhap it was this, the love that might have been, that lent to her softlyfeatured face at whiles a look, tense with suppressed meaning, that imparted a strange yearning tendency to the beautiful eyes, a charm few could resist. May I bring two men chums to witness the deed and take a snapshot? —May I? he said. —May I say a word to your telephone, missy? he asked roguishly. May I tempt you to a little more filleted lemon sole, miss Dubedat? May I trespass on your valuable space. Mayonnaise I poured on the plums thinking it was custard. May the God above Send down a dove With teeth as sharp as razors To slit the throats Of the English dogs That hanged our Irish leaders. May the good God bless him! May the twentysecond. May this pot of four half choke me, cried Costello, if she aint in the family way. May your shadow never grow less. M. B. loves a fair gentleman. McCann, one guinea. M’Coy. M’Coy nodded, picking at his moustache stubble. M’Coy peered into Marcus Tertius Moses’ sombre office, then at O’Neill’s clock. M’Coy said. M’Coy’s changed voice said. M’Coy’s white face smiled about it at instants and grew grave. M’Coy valise. M. Drumont, famous journalist, Drumont, know what he called queen Victoria? M. D. Scally, P. P.; the rev. Me? Me. —Me! Me? Me? Me? Me. Me. Me. Me? Meade’s timberyard. Meade’s yard. Mead of our fathers for the Übermensch. Mean bloody scut. Means something, language of flow. Meant nothing. Meanwhile the skill and patience of the physician had brought about a happy accouchement. Meditations of evolution increasingly vaster: of the moon invisible in incipient lunation, approaching perigee: of the infinite lattiginous scintillating uncondensed milky way, discernible by daylight by an observer placed at the lower end of a cylindrical vertical shaft 5000 ft deep sunk from the surface towards the centre of the earth: of Sirius alpha in Canis Maior 10 lightyears 57,000,000,000,000 miles distant and in volume 900 times the dimension of our planet: of Arcturus: of the precession of equinoxes: of Orion with belt and sextuple sun theta and nebula in which 100 of our solar systems could be contained: of moribund and of nascent new stars such as Nova in 1901: of our system plunging towards the constellation of Hercules: of the parallax or parallactic drift of socalled fixed stars, in reality evermoving wanderers from immeasurably remote eons to infinitely remote futures in comparison with which the years, threescore and ten, of allotted human life formed a parenthesis of infinitesimal brevity. Meet one Sunday after the rosary. Meet you knocking around. Megeggaggegg! Meh. Me have a nice pace. Me in his eyes. Melancholy God! Melting breast ointments for him! Me, Magee and Mulligan. Member for College green. Member of the corporation too. MEMORABLE BATTLES RECALLED —North Cork militia! the editor cried, striding to the mantelpiece. —Memorable bloody bridge battle and seven minutes’ war, Stephen assented, between Skinner’s alley and Ormond market. Memories beset his brooding brain. Memory! Me nantee saltee. Mendicancy: that of the fraudulent bankrupt with negligible assets paying 1/4d in the £, sandwichman, distributor of throwaways, nocturnal vagrant, insinuating sycophant, maimed sailor, blind stripling, superannuated bailiff’s man, marfeast, lickplate, spoilsport, pickthank, eccentric public laughingstock seated on bench of public park under discarded perforated umbrella. Men like that. Men, men, men. Men’s arms frankly round their stunted forms. Menton, John Henry, solicitor, commissioner for oaths and affidavits. Men trampling down women and children. Men wondered. Mercadante: seven last words. Merci. Merci. Merciful providence had been pleased to put a period to the sufferings of the lady who was enceinte which she had borne with a laudable fortitude and she had given birth to a bouncing boy. Mercurial Malachi. Mercurial Malachi! Mercy of God the sun was in his eyes or he’d have left him for dead. Mercy on the luckless! Mere fact of music shows you are. Meretricious finery to deceive the eye. —Merrion square style. Mervyn Browne. —Me? says Alf. Me see. Meseems it dureth overlong. Meshuggah. MESIAS: To alteration one pair trousers eleven shillings. Me sits there with his augur’s rod of ash, in borrowed sandals, by day beside a livid sea, unbeheld, in violet night walking beneath a reign of uncouth stars. Messages of condolence and sympathy are being hourly received from all parts of the different continents and the sovereign pontiff has been graciously pleased to decree that a special missa pro defunctis shall be celebrated simultaneously by the ordinaries of each and every cathedral church of all the episcopal dioceses subject to the spiritual authority of the Holy See in suffrage of the souls of those faithful departed who have been so unexpectedly called away from our midst. Messenger boys stealing to put on sixpence. Messenger took out his matchbox thoughtfully and lit his cigar. Messer Brunetto, I thank thee for the word. Messiah! Messrs Callan, Coleman. Messrs Pick and Pocket have power of attorney. Metaphysics in Mecklenburgh street! —Metempsychosis? Metempsychosis. —Metempsychosis, he said, frowning. —Metempsychosis, he said, is what the ancient Greeks called it. Met her once in the park. Met him pike hoses. Met him pike hoses. Met him pike hoses she called it till I told her about the transmigration. —Met him what? he asked. Method in his madness. Methodist husband. Meyerbeer. —Mezzo. Mezzo sovrano più... M. Fifteen yesterday. Mgr M’Manus, V. G.; the rev. —M’Guinness’s. —Miaow! he said in answer. MICHAEL, ARCHBISHOP OF ARMAGH: Pours a cruse of hairoil over Bloom’s head. Michaelmas goose. Midnight chimes from distant steeples. Midway, his last resistance yielding, he allowed his bowels to ease themselves quietly as he read, reading still patiently that slight constipation of yesterday quite gone. Might be all feeding on tabloids that time. Might be false name however like my name and the address Dolphin’s barn a blind. Might be happy all the same that way. Might be his house. Might be money. Might be settling my braces. Might be still up. Might be the fellow balked me this morning with that horsey woman. Might be the one bit me, come back to see. Might be what you like, till you hear the words. Might chance on a pair in the railway lost property office. Might get piles myself. Might go first himself. Might have lost my life too with that mangongwheeltracktrolleyglarejuggernaut only for presence of mind. Might have made a worse fool of myself however. Might have taken me to Malahide or a siding for the night or collision. Might he become a gentleman farmer of field produce and live stock? Might just walk into her here. Might learn to play. Might manage a sketch. Might meet a robber or two. Might remain. Might stop him giving credit another time. Might take an objection. Might take a trip down there. Might work a press pass. Mild, benign, rectorial, reproving, the head of Don John Conmee rises from the pianola coffin. Mild fire of wine kindled his veins. Miles of ears of porches. Miles of it unreeled. —Milk for the pussens, he said. Milly. Milly. Milly Bloom, fairhaired, greenvested, slimsandalled, her blue scarf in the seawind simply swirling, breaks from the arms of her lover and calls, her young eyes wonderwide. Milly delighted with Molly’s new blouse. Milly for example drying her handkerchief on the mirror to save the ironing. Milly has a position down in Mullingar, you know. MILLY: My! Milly, no sign of funk. Milly no taste. Milly served me that cutlet with a sprig of parsley. Milly’s tubbing night. Milly too. Milly too rock oil and flour. Milly tucked up in beddyhouse. Milly was a kiddy then. Milly young student. MINA KENNEDY: Her eyes upturned. Mina Kennedy, 4 Lismore terrace, Drumcondra with Idolores, a queen, Dolores, silent. Mina Kennedy served. Mina loved that song. —Mina Purefoy? she said. Mina Purefoy swollen belly on a bed groaning to have a child tugged out of her. Mind! Mind C. K. doesn’t pile it on. —Mind, Joe, says I. Mind Maggy doesn’t pawn it on you. Mind till I see. ... mind who you’re pinching... are you staying the night or a short time?... who did?... you’re a liar, excuse me... the gentleman paid down like a gentleman... drink... it’s long after eleven. Mind you don’t get one bang on the ear. —Mind you, I’m not saying that it’s all a pure invention, he resumed. Mind your cornflowers. Mind your steps there. Mine. Mine host bowed again as he made answer: —What say you, good masters, to a squab pigeon pasty, some collops of venison, a saddle of veal, widgeon with crisp hog’s bacon, a boar’s head with pistachios, a bason of jolly custard, a medlar tansy and a flagon of old Rhenish? Mine host came forth at the summons, girding him with his tabard. Mine is far and his secret as our eyes. Mine over there towards Finglas, the plot I bought. Mine too. Minette? —Mine would be often empty, Stephen said. Mingo, minxi, mictum, mingere. Minor chord comes now. —M’Intosh, Hynes said scribbling. Minuet of Don Giovanni he’s playing now. Mirage. Mirror there. Mirthless high malicious laughter. Mirus bazaar. Mirus bazaar fireworks go up from all sides with symbolical phallopyrotechnic designs. Misconduct of society belle. Misery! Misery! Misery. Miss bronze unbloused her neck. Miss Douce, bending over the teatray, ruffled again her nose and rolled droll fattened eyes. Miss Douce chimed in in deep bronze laughter, shouting: —And your other eye! Miss Douce composed her rose to wait. Miss Douce, engaging, Lydia Douce, bowed to suave solicitor, George Lidwell, gentleman, entering. Miss Douce grunted in snuffy fogey’s tone: —For your what? says he. Miss Douce halfstood to see her skin askance in the barmirror gildedlettered where hock and claret glasses shimmered and in their midst a shell. Miss Douce huffed and snorted down her nostrils that quivered imperthnthn like a snout in quest. Miss Douce, miss Lydia, did not believe: miss Kennedy, Mina, did not believe: George Lidwell, no: miss Dou did not: the first, the first: gent with the tank: believe, no, no: did not, miss Kenn: Lidlydiawell: the tank. Miss Douce of satin douced her arm away. Miss Douce reached high to take a flagon, stretching her satin arm, her bust, that all but burst, so high. Miss Douce said yes, sitting with his ex, pearl grey and eau de Nil. Miss Douce’s brave eyes, unregarded, turned from the crossblind, smitten by sunlight. Miss Douce took Boylan’s coin, struck boldly the cashregister. Miss Douce turned to her tea aside. Miss Douce withdrew her satiny arm, reproachful, pleased. Miss Dunne clicked on the keyboard: —16 June 1904. Miss Dunne hid the Capel street library copy of The Woman in White far back in her drawer and rolled a sheet of gaudy notepaper into her typewriter. Miss gaze of Kennedy, heard, not seen, read on. Missionary to Europe after fiery Columbanus. Miss Kennedy lipped her cup again, raised, drank a sip and gigglegiggled. Miss Kennedy passed their way flower, wonder who gave, bearing away teatray. Miss Kennedy, pouring now a fulldrawn tea, grimaced and prayed: —O, don’t remind me of him for mercy’ sake! Miss Kennedy sauntered sadly from bright light, twining a loose hair behind an ear. Miss Kennedy served two gentlemen with tankards of cool stout. Miss Kennedy smirked, disserving, coral lips, at first, at second. Miss Kennedy unplugged her ears to hear, to speak: but said, but prayed again: —Don’t let me think of him or I’ll expire. Miss Kennedy with manners transposed the teatray down to an upturned lithia crate, safe from eyes, low. Miss Kenn out of earshot. Miss Mina Kennedy brought near her lips to ear of tankard one. Miss puny little Edy’s countenance fell to no slight extent and Gerty could see by her looking as black as thunder that she was simply in a towering rage though she hid it, the little kinnatt, because that shaft had struck home for her petty jealousy and they both knew that she was something aloof, apart, in another sphere, that she was not of them and never would be and there was somebody else too that knew it and saw it so they could put that in their pipe and smoke it. Miss voice of Kennedy answered, a second teacup poised, her gaze upon a page: —No. Mistake must be: someone else. Mistaken identity. Mistake of nature. Mistake to hit back. Mister Knowall. Misters very selects for is pleasure must to visit heaven and hell show with mortuary candles and they tears silver which occur every night. Mistress! Mi trema un poco il. Mity cheese. —Mkgnao! —Mm, Mr Bloom said. Mnemo? Mnemo. Mnemo? Mob gaping. Mocking is catch. Mohammed cut a piece out of his mantle not to wake her. Moi faire, she said, Tous les messieurs. Moi, je suis socialiste. Moist pith of farls of bread, the froggreen wormwood, her matin incense, court the air. Moisture about gives long sight perhaps. Molecules all change. Molesworth street is opposite. Moll! Moll... Molly. Molly. Molly and Floey Dillon linked under the lilactree, laughing. Molly and Josie Powell. Molly and Mrs Fleming making the bed. Molly and Mrs Moisel. Molly did laugh when he went out. Molly drawing on the frosted carriagepane at Kingstown. Molly fondling him in her lap. Molly gets swelled after cabbage. Molly great dab at seeing anyone looking. Molly had that elephantgrey dress with the braided frogs. Molly, he. Molly, her underjaw stuck out, head back, about the farmer in the ridingboots and spurs at the horse show. Molly in Citron’s basketchair. Molly in her shift in Lombard street west, hair down. Molly in quis est homo: Mercadante. Molly, lieutenant Mulvey that kissed her under the Moorish wall beside the gardens. Molly looks out of plumb. Molly often told me feel things a ton weight. Molly’s best friend! Molly spitting them out. Molly tasting it, her veil up. Molly, that hurdygurdy boy. Molly too. Molly wanting to do it at the window. Molly was in fine voice that day, the Stabat Mater of Rossini. Moment before the next Lessing says. Moment more. Mona, my own love. Mona, my true love. Monasteries and convents. Monday he died. Monday morning. Money. Money? Money I haven’t. Money is power. Money was no object, he said, nor would he take a penny for his pains. Money worry. Mon fils, soldier of France. Monkeydoodle the whole thing. —Monks! —Monks! Monks of the screw. —Monks, sir? a voice asked from the castingbox. Monkwords, marybeads jabber on their girdles: roguewords, tough nuggets patter in their pockets. —Mon père, oui. —Monsieur de la Palice, Stephen sneered, was alive fifteen minutes before his death. —Monsieur Moore, he said, lecturer on French letters to the youth of Ireland. Monthly or effect of the other. Month’s mind: Quinlan. Moo. Mooney’s en ville, Mooney’s sur mer, the Moira, Larchet’s, Holles street hospital, Burke’s. Moonlight silver effulgence. Moooikill A Aitcha Ha ignorant as a kish of brogues, worth fifty thousand pounds. Moore asked him to bring Haines. Moored under the trees of Charleville Mall Father Conmee saw a turfbarge, a towhorse with pendent head, a bargeman with a hat of dirty straw seated amidships, smoking and staring at a branch of poplar above him. Moore is the man for it. Moore would say. Moorish. Moorish eyes. Mor! Moral pub. More! More active air, a matutinal distant cock, ecclesiastical clocks at various points, avine music, the isolated tread of an early wayfarer, the visible diffusion of the light of an invisible luminous body, the first golden limb of the resurgent sun perceptible low on the horizon. More bluggy drunkables? More dead for her than for me. More genially. More harm than good. More, houri, more. More in her line. More interesting if they told you what they were. More interesting if you understood what it was all about. More Irish than the Irish. More like ’tis the hoose or the timber tongue. Moreover, on the free surface of the lake in Stephen’s green amid inverted reflections of trees her uncommented spit, describing concentric circles of waterrings, indicated by the constancy of its permanence the locus of a somnolent prostrate fish cf mousewatching cat. More power, citizen. More power, Pat. More power the Cavan girl. More put out about a hole in her stocking. More room if they buried them standing. More sensible to spend the money on some charity for the living. More shameless not seeing. More tell me, more still! More than doctor or solicitor. More women than men in the world. Morituri te salutant. Morning after the bazaar dance when May’s band played Ponchielli’s dance of the hours. Morning mouth bad images. Morning, noon and twilight hours retreat before them. Morny Cannon is riding him. Morose delectation Aquinas tunbelly calls this, frate porcospino. —Morrow, nephew. Mortacci sui! Mortal! Mortal! Mortar and pestle. Mort aux vaches, says Frank then in the French language that had been indentured to a brandyshipper that has a winelodge in Bordeaux and he spoke French like a gentleman too. Mosenthal. Moses and the promised land. Moses begat Noah and Noah begat Eunuch and Eunuch begat O’Halloran and O’Halloran begat Guggenheim and Guggenheim begat Agendath and Agendath begat Netaim and Netaim begat Le Hirsch and Le Hirsch begat Jesurum and Jesurum begat MacKay and MacKay begat Ostrolopsky and Ostrolopsky begat Smerdoz and Smerdoz begat Weiss and Weiss begat Schwarz and Schwarz begat Adrianopoli and Adrianopoli begat Aranjuez and Aranjuez begat Lewy Lawson and Lewy Lawson begat Ichabudonosor and Ichabudonosor begat O’Donnell Magnus and O’Donnell Magnus begat Christbaum and Christbaum begat ben Maimun and ben Maimun begat Dusty Rhodes and Dusty Rhodes begat Benamor and Benamor begat Jones-Smith and Jones-Smith begat Savorgnanovich and Savorgnanovich begat Jasperstone and Jasperstone begat Vingtetunieme and Vingtetunieme begat Szombathely and Szombathely begat Virag and Virag begat Bloom et vocabitur nomen eius Emmanuel. Moses Dlugacz, ferreteyed albino, in blue dungarees, stands up in the gallery, holding in each hand an orange citron and a pork kidney. Moses Montefiore. Most amazingly sorry! Most amusing expressions that man finds. Most beautiful book come out of Ireland my time. Most beautiful tenor air ever written, Richie said: Sonnambula. Most bloody awful demirep! Most brutal thing. Most deciduously. Most licentious custom. Most of all he commented adversely on the desertion of Stephen by all his pubhunting confrères but one, a most glaring piece of ratting on the part of his brother medicos under all the circs. Most of all he liked grilled mutton kidneys which gave to his palate a fine tang of faintly scented urine. Most of us thought as much. —Most pertinent question, the professor said between his chews. Most scandalous revelation. Most trenchant rendition of that ballad, upon my soul and honour it is. MOTHER GROGAN: Removes her boot to throw it at Bloom. Mother Grogan throws her boot at Bloom. Mother Grogan was, one imagines, a kinswoman of Mary Ann. Mother of Moses! Mother’s deathbed. Mother Shipton’s prophecy that is about ships around they fly in the twinkling. Mother Slipperslapper. Mothers’ meeting. Mother’s milk, Purefoy, the milk of human kin, milk too of those burgeoning stars overhead rutilant in thin rainvapour, punch milk, such as those rioters will quaff in their guzzling den, milk of madness, the honeymilk of Canaan’s land. Mount Carmel. Mount him on the camel or the boisterous buffalo the victory in a hack canter is still his. Mount street way. Mourners came out through the gates: woman and a girl. Mourners coming out. Mournful he whistled. —Mournful mummer, Buck Mulligan moaned. Mourning coaches drawn up, drowning their grief. Mourning too. Mouth dry. Mouth fallen open. Mouth made for that. Mouth to her kiss. Mouth to her mouth’s kiss. Moutonner, the French said. Moutpat. Move on out of that. Moves to one great goal. Moving through the air high spars of a threemaster, her sails brailed up on the crosstrees, homing, upstream, silently moving, a silent ship. Moya. Mozart’s twelfth mass: Gloria in that. Mr Allfours Tamoshant. Mr Allfours: The answer is in the negative. Mr and Mrs Wyse Conifer Neaulan will spend a quiet honeymoon in the Black Forest. Mr Best asked. Mr Best asked with slight concern. Mr Best came forward, amiable, towards his colleague. Mr Best eagerquietly lifted his book to say: —That’s very interesting because that brother motive, don’t you know, we find also in the old Irish myths. Mr Best entered, tall, young, mild, light. Mr Best piped. Mr Best pleaded. Mr Best’s face, appealed to, agreed. Mr Best’s quiet voice said forgetfully. Mr Best turned to him. Mr B interrogated. Mr Bloom, about to speak, closed his lips again. Mr Bloom actuated by motives of inherent delicacy inasmuch as he always believed in minding his own business moved off but nevertheless remained on the qui vive with just a shade of anxiety though not funkyish in the least. Mr Bloom admired the caretaker’s prosperous bulk. Mr Bloom, alone, looked at the titles. Mr Bloom and Stephen entered the cabman’s shelter, an unpretentious wooden structure, where, prior to then, he had rarely if ever been before, the former having previously whispered to the latter a few hints anent the keeper of it said to be the once famous Skin-the-Goat Fitzharris, the invincible, though he could not vouch for the actual facts which quite possibly there was not one vestige of truth in. Mr Bloom asked. Mr Bloom asked. Mr Bloom asked. Mr Bloom asked. Mr Bloom asked. Mr Bloom asked. Mr Bloom asked. Mr Bloom asked, taking the card. Mr Bloom asked, turning to Mr Dedalus. Mr Bloom ate his strips of sandwich, fresh clean bread, with relish of disgust pungent mustard, the feety savour of green cheese. Mr Bloom at gaze saw a lithe young man, clad in mourning, a wide hat. Mr Bloom, availing himself of the right of free speech, he having just a bowing acquaintance with the language in dispute, though, to be sure, rather in a quandary over voglio, remarked to his protégé in an audible tone of voice à propos of the battle royal in the street which was still raging fast and furious: —A beautiful language. Mr Bloom began to speak with sudden eagerness to his companions’ faces. Mr Bloom beheld it. Mr Bloom, breathless, caught in a whirl of wild newsboys near the offices of the Irish Catholic and Dublin Penny Journal, called: —Mr Crawford! Mr Bloom came last folding his paper again into his pocket. Mr Bloom came to Kildare street. Mr Bloom, champing, standing, looked upon his sigh. Mr Bloom, chapfallen, drew behind a few paces so as not to overhear. Mr Bloom closed his eyes and sadly twice bowed his head. Mr Bloom coasted warily. Mr Bloom could easily picture his advent on this scene, the homecoming to the mariner’s roadside shieling after having diddled Davy Jones, a rainy night with a blind moon. Mr Bloom cut his sandwich into slender strips. Mr Bloom effaced the letters with his slow boot. Mr Bloom ejaculated, professing not the least surprise at the intelligence, I can quite credit the assertion and I guarantee he invariably does. Mr Bloom entered and sat in the vacant place. Mr Bloom folded the sheets again to a neat square and lodged the soap in it, smiling. Mr Bloom gave prudent assent. Mr Bloom gazed across the road at the outsider drawn up before the door of the Grosvenor. Mr Bloom glanced about him and then stood up, looking over the risen hats. Mr Bloom glanced from his angry moustache to Mr Power’s mild face and Martin Cunningham’s eyes and beard, gravely shaking. Mr Bloom, glancing sideways up from the cross he had made, saw the foreman’s sallow face, think he has a touch of jaundice, and beyond the obedient reels feeding in huge webs of paper. Mr Bloom inquired. Mr Bloom inserted his nose. Mr Bloom in the meanwhile kept dodging about in the vicinity of the cobblestones near the brazier of coke in front of the corporation watchman’s sentrybox who evidently a glutton for work, it struck him, was having a quiet forty winks for all intents and purposes on his own private account while Dublin slept. Mr Bloom looked back towards the choir. Mr Bloom moved behind the portly kindly caretaker. Mr Bloom moved forward, raising his troubled eyes. Mr Bloom moved nimbly aside. Mr Bloom nodded gravely looking in the quick bloodshot eyes. Mr Bloom on his way out raised three fingers in greeting. Mr Bloom passed on out of the clanking noises through the gallery on to the landing. Mr Bloom pointed quickly. Mr Bloom promptly did as suggested and removed the incriminated article, a blunt hornhandled ordinary knife with nothing particularly Roman or antique about it to the lay eye, observing that the point was the least conspicuous point about it. Mr Bloom pursued without flinching a hairsbreadth. Mr Bloom put his face forward to catch the words. Mr Bloom put his head out of the window. Mr Bloom put on his hat and saw the portly figure make its way deftly through the maze of graves. Mr Bloom, quickbreathing, slowlier walking passed Adam court. Mr Bloom raised a cake to his nostrils. Mr Bloom raised two fingers doubtfully to his lips. Mr Bloom reached Essex bridge. Mr Bloom read again: The beautiful woman. Mr Bloom reviewed the nails of his left hand, then those of his right hand. Mr Bloom said. Mr Bloom said, and I’ll take it round to the Telegraph office. Mr Bloom said eagerly. Mr Bloom said simply. Mr Bloom said slowly: —Well, he is one of our saviours also. Mr Bloom, scarcely knowing which way to look, turned away on the moment flusterfied but outwardly calm, and, picking up from the table the pink sheet of the Abbey street organ which the jarvey, if such he was, had laid aside, he picked it up and looked at the pink of the paper though why pink. Mr Bloom, seeing the coast clear, made for the inner door. Mr Bloom set his thigh down. Mr Bloom’s eye followed its line and saw again the dyeworks’ van drawn up before Drago’s. Mr Bloom’s glance travelled down the edge of the paper, scanning the deaths: Callan, Coleman, Dignam, Fawcett, Lowry, Naumann, Peake, what Peake is that? is it the chap was in Crosbie and Alleyne’s? no, Sexton, Urbright. Mr Bloom’s hand unbuttoned his hip pocket swiftly and transferred the paperstuck soap to his inner handkerchief pocket. Mr Bloom smiled joylessly on Ringsend road. Mr Bloom smiled O rocks at two windows of the ballastoffice. Mr Bloom, so far as he was personally concerned, was just pondering in pensive mood. Mr Bloom’s sharp ears heard him then expectorate the plug probably which it was, so that he must have lodged it for the time being in his fist while he did the drinking and making water jobs and found it a bit sour after the liquid fire in question. Mr Bloom stood at the corner, his eyes wandering over the multicoloured hoardings. Mr Bloom stood behind near the font and, when all had knelt, dropped carefully his unfolded newspaper from his pocket and knelt his right knee upon it. Mr Bloom stood behind the boy with the wreath looking down at his sleekcombed hair and at the slender furrowed neck inside his brandnew collar. Mr Bloom stood by, hearing the loud throbs of cranks, watching the silent typesetters at their cases. Mr Bloom stood far back, his hat in his hand, counting the bared heads. Mr Bloom stood in his way. Mr Bloom stooped and turned over a piece of paper on the strand. Mr Bloom, strolling towards Brunswick street, smiled. Mr Bloom thoroughly acquiesced in the general gist of this though the mystical finesse involved was a bit out of his sublunary depth still he felt bound to enter a demurrer on the head of simple, promptly rejoining: —Simple? Mr Bloom took the paper from his inside pocket. Mr Bloom took up his cutting. Mr Bloom touched her funnybone gently, warning her: —Mind! Mr Bloom turned and saw the liveried porter raise his lettered cap as a stately figure entered between the newsboards of the Weekly Freeman and National Press and the Freeman’s Journal and National Press. Mr Bloom turned at Gray’s confectioner’s window of unbought tarts and passed the reverend Thomas Connellan’s bookstore. Mr Bloom turned away his face. Mr Bloom turned his largelidded eyes with unhasty friendliness. Mr Bloom turned over idly pages of The Awful Disclosures of Maria Monk, then of Aristotle’s Masterpiece. Mr Bloom unclasped his hands in a gesture of soft politeness and clasped them. Mr Bloom walked behind the eyeless feet, a flatcut suit of herringbone tweed. Mr Bloom walked on again easily, seeing ahead of him in sunlight the tight skullpiece, the dangling stickumbrelladustcoat. Mr Bloom walked towards Dawson street, his tongue brushing his teeth smooth. Mr Bloom walked unheeded along his grove by saddened angels, crosses, broken pillars, family vaults, stone hopes praying with upcast eyes, old Ireland’s hearts and hands. Mr Bloom was all at sea for a moment, seeing the others evidently eavesdropping too. Mr Bloom watched curiously, kindly the lithe black form. Mr Bloom went round the corner and passed the drooping nags of the hazard. Mr Bloom with careful hand recomposed his wet shirt. Mr Bloom with his argol bargol. Mr Bloom with his stick gently vexed the thick sand at his foot. Mr Bloom with open mouth, his left boot sanded sideways, leaned, breathed. Mr Bloom, without evincing surprise, unostentatiously turned over the card to peruse the partially obliterated address and postmark. —Mr Boylan! —Mr Brandes accepts it, Stephen said, as the first play of the closing period. Mr Byrne, sir, we’ll take two of your small Jamesons after that and a... Mr Cowe Conacre Multifarnham. Mr Cunningham’s letter. Mr Deasy asked. Mr Deasy asked. Mr Deasy asked as Stephen read on. Mr Deasy cried. Mr Deasy halted, breathing hard and swallowing his breath. Mr Deasy is calling you. Mr Deasy laughed with rich delight, putting back his savingsbox. Mr Deasy looked down and held for awhile the wings of his nose tweaked between his fingers. Mr Deasy said I was to copy them off the board, sir. Mr Deasy shook his head. Mr Deasy stared sternly for some moments over the mantelpiece at the shapely bulk of a man in tartan fillibegs: Albert Edward, prince of Wales. —Mr Deasy told me to write them out all again, he said, and show them to you, sir. —Mr Dedalus! Mr Dedalus! Mr Dedalus amid the din walked off, murmuring to himself with a pursing mincing mouth gently: —The little nuns! Mr Dedalus asked. Mr Dedalus asked. Mr Dedalus asked. Mr Dedalus asked. Mr Dedalus asked. Mr Dedalus asked, his tongue in his cheek. Mr Dedalus bent across to salute. Mr Dedalus covered himself quickly and got in, saying: —Yes, yes. Mr Dedalus cried. Mr Dedalus drew himself upright and tugged again at his moustache. Mr Dedalus exclaimed in fright. Mr Dedalus eyed with cold wandering scorn various points of Ben Dollard’s figure. Mr Dedalus, famous father, laid by his dry filled pipe. Mr Dedalus fell back, saying: —Was that Mulligan cad with him? Mr Dedalus laid his pipe to rest beside the tuningfork and, sitting, touched the obedient keys. Mr Dedalus looked after the stumping figure and said mildly: —The devil break the hasp of your back! Mr Dedalus nodded, looking out. Mr Dedalus, peering through his glasses towards the veiled sun, hurled a mute curse at the sky. Mr Dedalus placed his hands on them and held them back. Mr Dedalus said. Mr Dedalus said. Mr Dedalus said. Mr Dedalus said. Mr Dedalus said: —I am come to pay you another visit. Mr Dedalus said in subdued wonder. Mr Dedalus said, returning with fetched pipe. Mr Dedalus said, stretching over across. Mr Dedalus sighed. Mr Dedalus sighed resignedly. Mr Dedalus stared at him. Mr Dedalus, staring from the empty fireplace at Ned Lambert’s quizzing face, asked of it sourly: —Agonising Christ, wouldn’t it give you a heartburn on your arse? Mr Dedalus struck, whizzed, lit, puffed savoury puff after —Irish? Mr Dedalus thought and nodded. Mr Dedalus, tugging a long moustache, came round from Williams’s row. Mr Dedalus, twisting his nose, frowned downward and said: —Unless I’m greatly mistaken. Mr Dedalus wandered back, pipe in hand. Mr Denis J Maginni, professor of dancing &c, in silk hat, slate frockcoat with silk facings, white kerchief tie, tight lavender trousers, canary gloves and pointed patent boots, walking with grave deportment most respectfully took the curbstone as he passed lady Maxwell at the corner of Dignam’s court. Mr Dixon, to turn the table, took on to ask of Mr Mulligan himself whether his incipient ventripotence, upon which he rallied him, betokened an ovoblastic gestation in the prostatic utricle or male womb or was due, as with the noted physician, Mr Austin Meldon, to a wolf in the stomach. Mr Dollard. —Mr Dollard, they murmured low. Mr F. Alexander’s Throwaway, b. h. by Rightaway-Thrale, 5 yrs, 9 st 4 lbs W. Lane 1. Mr Fox! Mr Garrett Deasy. Mr Justice Fitzgibbon’s door that is to sit with Mr Healy the lawyer upon the college lands Mal. Mr Justice Fitzgibbon, the present lord justice of appeal, had spoken and the paper under debate was an essay new for those days, advocating the revival of the Irish tongue. Mr Kernan added: —The service of the Irish church used in Mount Jerome is simpler, more impressive I must say. Mr Kernan and Ned Lambert followed, Hynes walking after them. Mr Kernan approached Island street. Mr Kernan assured him. Mr Kernan glanced in farewell at his image. Mr Kernan halted and preened himself before the sloping mirror of Peter Kennedy, hairdresser. Mr Kernan hurried forward, blowing pursily. Mr Kernan, pleased with the order he had booked, walked boldly along James’s street. Mr Kernan said with reproof. Mr Kernan said with solemnity: —I am the resurrection and the life. Mr Kernan turned and walked down the slope of Watling street by the corner of Guinness’s visitors’ waitingroom. —Mrkgnao! the cat cried. —Mrkrgnao! the cat said loudly. Mr Lambe from London. Mr Lenehan, yes. —Mr Lyster, an attendant said from the door ajar. Mr MacTrigger. Mr Magee, sir, there’s a gentleman to see you. Mr M. Mulligan Hyg. et Eug. Mr Mulligan accepted of the invitation and, expatiating upon his design, told his hearers that he had been led into this thought by a consideration of the causes of sterility, both the inhibitory and the prohibitory, whether the inhibition in its turn were due to conjugal vexations or to a parsimony of the balance as well as whether the prohibition proceeded from defects congenital or from proclivities acquired. Mr Mulligan however made court to the scholarly by an apt quotation from the classics which, as it dwelt upon his memory, seemed to him a sound and tasteful support of his contention: Talis ac tanta depravatio hujus seculi, O quirites, ut matresfamiliarum nostrae lascivas cujuslibet semiviri libici titillationes testibus ponderosis atque excelsis erectionibus centurionum Romanorum magnopere anteponunt, while for those of ruder wit he drove home his point by analogies of the animal kingdom more suitable to their stomach, the buck and doe of the forest glade, the farmyard drake and duck. Mr Mulligan, I’ll be bound, has his theory too of the play and of Shakespeare. Mr Mulligan, now perceiving the table, asked for whom were those loaves and fishes and, seeing the stranger, he made him a civil bow and said, Pray, sir, was you in need of any professional assistance we could give? Mr Mulligan was civil enough to express some relish of it all the more as it jumped with a project of his own for the cure of the very evil that had been touched on. Mr Nannetti considered the cutting awhile and nodded. Mr O’Connell shook all their hands in silence. Mr O’Madden Burke asked. Mr O’Madden Burke fell back with grace on his umbrella, feigning a gasp. Mr O’Madden Burke, following close, said with an ally’s lunge of his umbrella: —Lay on, Macduff! Mr O’Madden Burke’s sphinx face reriddled. Mr O’Madden Burke, tall in copious grey of Donegal tweed, came in from the hallway. Mr Orelli O’Reilly Montenotte. Mr Power and Mr Dedalus followed. Mr Power asked. Mr Power asked. Mr Power asked. Mr Power asked: —How is the concert tour getting on, Bloom? Mr Power asked through both windows. Mr Power, collapsing in laughter, shaded his face from the window as the carriage passed Gray’s statue. Mr Power gazed at the passing houses with rueful apprehension. Mr Power pointed. Mr Power said, wiping his wet eyes with his fingers. Mr Power’s choked laugh burst quietly in the carriage. Mr Power sent a long laugh down his shaded nostrils. Mr Power’s soft eyes went up to the apex of the lofty cone. Mr Power stepped in after him, curving his height with care. Mr Power took his arm. Mr Power whispered. Mr Power whispered. Mr President, you come long and help me save our sisters dear. Mr Russell, rumour has it, is gathering together a sheaf of our younger poets’ verses. Mrs Bandmann Palmer. Mrs Beaufoy, Purefoy. MRS BELLINGHAM: He addressed me in several handwritings with fulsome compliments as a Venus in furs and alleged profound pity for my frostbound coachman Palmer while in the same breath he expressed himself as envious of his earflaps and fleecy sheepskins and of his fortunate proximity to my person, when standing behind my chair wearing my livery and the armorial bearings of the Bellingham escutcheon garnished sable, a buck’s head couped or. MRS BELLINGHAM: In cap and seal coney mantle, wrapped up to the nose, steps out of her brougham and scans through tortoiseshell quizzing-glasses which she takes from inside her huge opossum muff. MRS BELLINGHAM: Me too. Mrs Bellingham, Mrs Yelverton Barry and the Honourable Mrs Mervyn Talboys rush forward with their handkerchiefs to sop it up. Mrs Riordan Dante, a widow of independent means, had resided in the house of Stephen’s parents from 1 September 1888 to 29 December 1891 and had also resided during the years 1892, 1893 and 1894 in the City Arms Hotel owned by Elizabeth O’Dowd of 54 Prussia street where, during parts of the years 1893 and 1894, she had been a constant informant of Bloom who resided also in the same hotel, being at that time a clerk in the employment of Joseph Cuffe of 5 Smithfield for the superintendence of sales in the adjacent Dublin Cattle market on the North Circular road. MRS RIORDAN: Tears up her will. Mr Staylewit Buncombe. Mr Stephen, a little moved but very handsomely told him no such matter and that he had dispatches from the emperor’s chief tailtickler thanking him for the hospitality, that was sending over Doctor Rinderpest, the bestquoted cowcatcher in all Muscovy, with a bolus or two of physic to take the bull by the horns. MRS THORNTON: In nursetender’s gown. MRS YELVERTON BARRY: Disgraceful!
