So here’s to disciples and Calvary. So he’s gone. So he starts telling us about corporal punishment and about the crew of tars and officers and rearadmirals drawn up in cocked hats and the parson with his protestant bible to witness punishment and a young lad brought out, howling for his ma, and they tie him down on the buttend of a gun. So he told Terry to bring some water for the dog and, gob, you could hear him lapping it up a mile off. So he took a bundle of wisps of letters and envelopes out of his pocket. So he was. So he was before he got the job in the morgue under Louis Byrne. So he was, faith. So he went over to the biscuit tin Bob Doran left to see if there was anything he could lift on the nod, the old cur after him backing his luck with his mangy snout up. So howandever, as I was saying, the old dog seeing the tin was empty starts mousing around by Joe and me. —So I am, Ben Warrior laughed. So I carried the boat of incense then at Clongowes. So I just went round the back of the yard to pumpship and begob hundred shillings to five while I was letting off my Throwaway twenty to letting off my load gob says I to myself I knew he was uneasy in his two pints off of Joe and one in Slattery’s off in his mind to get off the mark to hundred shillings is five quid and when they were in the dark horse pisser Burke was telling me card party and letting on the child was sick gob, must have done about a gallon flabbyarse of a wife speaking down the tube she’s better or she’s ow! all a plan so he could vamoose with the pool if he won or Jesus, full up I was trading without a licence ow! So I landed them up on Behan’s car and down to nighttown. Soiled handkerchief: medicinebottle. Soiled personal linen, wrong side up with care. Soil must be simply swirling with them. So in comes Martin asking where was Bloom. So in the future, the sister of the past, I may see myself as I sit here now but by reflection from that which then I shall be. So in the moon’s midwatches I pace the path above the rocks, in sable silvered, hearing Elsinore’s tempting flood. So I saw there was going to be a bit of a dust. So it is. —So it is, Mr Dedalus said. So it returns. —So it was, begad, Ned Lambert agreed. So I without deviating from plain facts in the least told him his God, I mean Christ, was a jew too and all his family like me though in reality I’m not. So J. J. ordered the drinks. So J. J. puts in a word, doing the toff about one story was good till you heard another and blinking facts and the Nelson policy, putting your blind eye to the telescope and drawing up a bill of attainder to impeach a nation, and Bloom trying to back him up moderation and botheration and their colonies and their civilisation. So Joe starts telling the citizen about the foot and mouth disease and the cattle traders and taking action in the matter and the citizen sending them all to the rightabout and Bloom coming out with his sheepdip for the scab and a hoose drench for coughing calves and the guaranteed remedy for timber tongue. So Joe took up the letters. Soldier and civilian. Solemn. Solemn as Troy. Solemnly he came forward and mounted the round gunrest. Solicitor, I think. So long as women don’t mock what matter? So may the Creator deal with me. Some animal. Somebody would be dreadfully jealous if she knew. Some chap in the blues. SOME COLUMN!—THAT’S WHAT WADDLER ONE SAID —That’s new, Myles Crawford said. —Some, Dilly said. Some flatfoot tramp on it in the morning. Some girl. Some good matronly woman in a porkpie hat to mother him. Some H2O for a gent fainted. Some Kildare street club toff had it probably. Some laughed again: mirthless but with meaning. Some light still. Some man that wayfaring was stood by housedoor at night’s oncoming. Some of that old sacred music splendid. Someone has laid a bunch of flowers there. —Someone killed her, Stephen said gloomily. Someone ought to take them and give them a good hiding for themselves to keep them in their places, the both of them. —Someone saluted you, Mr Bloom said. —Someone seems to have been making a picnic party here lately, Mr Power said. Someone taking a rise out of him. Someone that has nothing better to do ought to write a letter pro bono publico to the papers about the muzzling order for a dog the like of that. Someone walking over it. Someone was to read them there after a few thousand years, a mahamanvantara. —Some people believe, he said, that we go on living in another body after death, that we lived before. —Some people, says Bloom, can see the mote in others’ eyes but they can’t see the beam in their own. Some person or persons invisible directed him to the male urinal erected by the cleansing committee all over the place for the purpose but after a brief space of time during which silence reigned supreme the sailor, evidently giving it a wide berth, eased himself closer at hand, the noise of his bilgewater some little time subsequently splashing on the ground where it apparently awoke a horse of the cabrank. Some pock or oth. Some reason. Some say they remember their past lives. Some school treat. Something about withering plants I read in a garden. Something confused. Something detective read off blottingpad. Something evidently riled them in his death. —Something for you, the professor explained to Myles Crawford. Something galoptious. Something going on: some sodality. Something green it would have to be: spinach, say. Something he buried there, his grandmother. Something in all those superstitions because when you go out never know what dangers. Something inside them goes pop. Something in the air. Something like those mazzoth: it’s that sort of bread: unleavened shewbread. Something new and easy. Something new to hope for not like the past she wanted back, waiting. Something occult: symbolism. Something pinned on: photo perhaps. Something poisonous I ate. Something quite ordinary. Something the nurse taught me. Something to catch the eye. Something to eat? Something to hand on. Something with a bite in it. Sometimes away for years at the ends of the earth somewhere. Sometimes children turn out well enough. Sometimes Molly and Milly together. Sometimes they go off. —Some time yesterday, Stephen said. Some Tipperary bosthoon endangering the lives of the citizens. Some, to example, there are again whose movements are automatic. Some trouble is on here. Someway in his. Somewhere. Somewhere here lord Edward Fitzgerald escaped from major Sirr. Somewhere imperceptibly he would hear and somehow reluctantly, suncompelled, obey the summons of recall. Somewhere in Cabra, what? Somewhere in the east: early morning: set off at dawn. Somewhere to someone in your flutiest voice. Some women, instance, warn you off when they have their period. Somnambulist. Sons with mothers, sires with daughters, lesbic sisters, loves that dare not speak their name, nephews with grandmothers, jailbirds with keyholes, queens with prize bulls. So of course Bob Doran starts doing the bloody fool with him: —Give us the paw! So of course everyone had the laugh at Bloom and says he, trying to muck out of it: —Or also living in different places. So of course the citizen was only waiting for the wink of the word and he starts gassing out of him about the invincibles and the old guard and the men of sixtyseven and who fears to speak of ninetyeight and Joe with him about all the fellows that were hanged, drawn and transported for the cause by drumhead courtmartial and a new Ireland and new this, that and the other. So off they started about Irish sports and shoneen games the like of lawn tennis and about hurley and putting the stone and racy of the soil and building up a nation once again and all to that. So on. So on. Soon be a woman. Soon be calling him my lord mayor. Sooner have me as I am than some poet chap with bearsgrease plastery hair, lovelock over his dexter optic. Soon got, soon gone. Soon I am old. —Soot’s luck, says Joe. So over she went and when he saw her coming she could see him take his hand out of his pocket, getting nervous, and beginning to play with his watchchain, looking up at the church. SOPHIST WALLOPS HAUGHTY HELEN SQUARE ON PROBOSCIS. SPARTANS GNASH MOLARS. ITHACANS VOW PEN IS CHAMP. —You remind me of Antisthenes, the professor said, a disciple of Gorgias, the sophist. Sorra one o’ me knows. —Sorrow from me seemed to depart. Sorry I didn’t work him about getting Molly into the choir instead of that Father Farley who looked a fool but wasn’t. Sorry, Jack. —Sorry, Mr Bloom said. Sorry, sir: trouble. —So sad to look at his face, miss Douce condoled. So saying he knocked loudly with his swordhilt upon the open lattice. So saying he skipped around, nimbly considering, frankly at the same time apologetic to get on his companion’s right, a habit of his, by the bye, his right side being, in classical idiom, his tender Achilles. So similarly he had a very shrewd suspicion that Mr Johnny Lever got rid of some £. s. d. in the course of his perambulations round the docks in the congenial atmosphere of the Old Ireland tavern, come back to Erin and so on. So, Spain. So stood they there both awhile in wanhope sorrowing one with other. So Terry brought the three pints. So that gesture, not music not odour, would be a universal language, the gift of tongues rendering visible not the lay sense but the first entelechy, the structural rhythm. So the citizen takes up one of his paraphernalia papers and he starts reading out: —A delegation of the chief cotton magnates of Manchester was presented yesterday to His Majesty the Alaki of Abeakuta by Gold Stick in Waiting, Lord Walkup of Walkup on Eggs, to tender to His Majesty the heartfelt thanks of British traders for the facilities afforded them in his dominions. So then after that they drifted on to the wreck off Daunt’s rock, wreck of that illfated Norwegian barque nobody could think of her name for the moment till the jarvey who had really quite a look of Henry Campbell remembered it Palme on Booterstown strand. So then the citizen begins talking about the Irish language and the corporation meeting and all to that and the shoneens that can’t speak their own language and Joe chipping in because he stuck someone for a quid and Bloom putting in his old goo with his twopenny stump that he cadged off of Joe and talking about the Gaelic league and the antitreating league and drink, the curse of Ireland. So the scene between the pair of them, the licensee of the place rumoured to be or have been Fitzharris, the famous invincible, and the other, obviously bogus, reminded him forcibly as being on all fours with the confidence trick, supposing, that is, it was prearranged as the lookeron, a student of the human soul if anything, the others seeing least of the game. So the wife comes out top dog, what? So they started arguing about the point, Bloom saying he wouldn’t and he couldn’t and excuse him no offence and all to that and then he said well he’d just take a cigar. So they started talking about capital punishment and of course Bloom comes out with the why and the wherefore and all the codology of the business and the old dog smelling him all the time I’m told those jewies does have a sort of a queer odour coming off them for dogs about I don’t know what all deterrent effect and so forth and so on. So they turned on to chatting about music, a form of art for which Bloom, as a pure amateur, possessed the greatest love, as they made tracks arm in arm across Beresford place. So Thursday sixteenth June Patk. So to change the subject he read about Dignam R. I. Soulfully. Sound as a bell. Sound meat there: like a stallfed heifer. Sounds a bit silly till you come to look into it well. —Sounds are impostures, Stephen said after a pause of some little time, like names. Sounds better than last time I heard. Sounds solid: made by the mallet of Los Demiurgos. Soup, joint and sweet. Source of life. Sour pipe removed he held a shield of hand beside his lips that cooed a moonlight nightcall, clear from anear, a call from afar, replying. Souse in the ear sometimes. South Frederick street. South, pout, out, shout, drouth. South side anyhow. 1000 sovs with 3000 in specie. So warm. So were they all in their blind fancy, Mr Cavil and Mr Sometimes Godly, Mr Ape Swillale, Mr False Franklin, Mr Dainty Dixon, Young Boasthard and Mr Cautious Calmer. So we turned into Barney Kiernan’s and there, sure enough, was the citizen up in the corner having a great confab with himself and that bloody mangy mongrel, Garryowen, and he waiting for what the sky would drop in the way of drink. So we went around by the Linenhall barracks and the back of the courthouse talking of one thing or another. So womanly, full. So you catch no money. So you think... Space: what you damn well have to see. Spain again, you saw in the war, compared with goahead America. —Spaniards, for instance, he continued, passionate temperaments like that, impetuous as Old Nick, are given to taking the law into their own hands and give you your quietus doublequick with those poignards they carry in the abdomen. Spanish fly in his fly or mustard plaster on his dibble. Spanishy eyes. Spare my past. Sparkling bronze azure eyed Blazure’s skyblue bow and eyes. Spat-on sawdust, sweetish warmish cigarettesmoke, reek of plug, spilt beer, men’s beery piss, the stale of ferment. Spattered with size and lime of their lodges they frisk limblessly about him. Speak you englishman tongue for double entente cordiale. Specially in these black clothes feel it more. Spooks. —Spooning with him last night on the pier. SPOT THE WINNER Lenehan came out of the inner office with Sport’s tissues. Spouse and helpmate of Adam Kadmon: Heva, naked Eve. Squareheaded chaps those must be in Rome: they work the whole show. Square it you with the boss and we’ll split the job, see? Squarepushing up against a backdoor. Squealing cat. Squeezing or. Stable with those halfcastes. Staggering bob. Staggering Bob, a whitepolled calf, thrusts a ruminating head with humid nostrils through the foliage. STAGGERING BOB: Large teardrops rolling from his prominent eyes, snivels. Stag that one is! Stains on his coat. Stale. Stale smoky air hung in the study with the smell of drab abraded leather of its chairs. Stamps: stickyback pictures. Stand and deliver. —Stand and deliver, says he. Stand by. Standing? Standing perpendicular at the same door and on different sides of its base, the lines of their valedictory arms, meeting at any point and forming any angle less than the sum of two right angles. Stands a drink now and then. Stand up at the gospel of course. —Stand up straight for the love of the lord Jesus, Mr Dedalus said. —Stand up straight, girl, he said. Stand up to it then with force like men. Stand us a drink itself. Stap my vitals, said he, them was always the sentiments of honest Frank Costello which I was bred up most particular to honour thy father and thy mother that had the best hand to a rolypoly or a hasty pudding as you ever see what I always looks back on with a loving heart. Stare the sun for example like the eagle then look at a shoe see a blotch blob yellowish. Staring backers with square hats stood round the roped prizering. Stark ruth of man his errand that him lone led till that house. Stars all around suns turn roundabout. Start afresh. Starting united both at normal walking pace from Beresford place they followed in the order named Lower and Middle Gardiner streets and Mountjoy square, west: then, at reduced pace, each bearing left, Gardiner’s place by an inadvertence as far as the farther corner of Temple street: then, at reduced pace with interruptions of halt, bearing right, Temple street, north, as far as Hardwicke place. —Start, Palmerston Park! Stationer’s just here too. Staunch friend, a brother soul: Wilde’s love that dare not speak its name. Stave it off awhile. Stay, good friend. Stay in. Stays. Steadfast John replied severe: —The doctor can tell us what those words mean. Steady on. Steak and kidney. Steak and kidney pie. Steak, kidney, liver, mashed, at meat fit for princes sat princes Bloom and Goulding. Steal upon larks. Steel wine is said to cure snoring. Steered by an umbrella sword to the footlights: Mario the tenor. Steered by his rapier, he glides to the door, his wild harp slung behind him. Stephano Dedalo, alumno optimo, palmam ferenti. Stephanos, my crown. Stephen! Stephen! Stephen, abandoning his ashplant, his head and arms thrown back stark, beats the ground and flies from the room, past the whores at the door. STEPHEN: Abruptly. STEPHEN: Addressed her in vocative feminine. STEPHEN: Aha! STEPHEN: Ah non, par exemple! STEPHEN: Altius aliquantulum. STEPHEN: Amiably. Stephen and Bloom gaze in the mirror. Stephen and Florry turn cumbrously. Stephen and Zoe circle freely. Stephen, an elbow rested on the jagged granite, leaned his palm against his brow and gazed at the fraying edge of his shiny black coat-sleeve. Stephen answered himself. Stephen anyhow lent him one of them. STEPHEN: Anyway, who wants two gestures to illustrate a loaf and a jug? Stephen, arming Zoe with exaggerated grace, begins to waltz her round the room. STEPHEN: As a matter of fact it is of no importance whether Benedetto Marcello found it or made it. Stephen asked. Stephen asked. Stephen asked. Stephen asked. Stephen asked. Stephen asked. Stephen asked, beginning to smile. Stephen asked her. Stephen asked, opening another book. STEPHEN: A time, times and half a time. STEPHEN: At the pianola, making a gesture of abhorrence. Stephen bent forward and peered at the mirror held out to him, cleft by a crooked crack. STEPHEN: Break my spirit, will he? STEPHEN: Brings the match near his eye. STEPHEN: Cardinal sin. STEPHEN: Catches sight of Lynch’s and Kitty’s heads. STEPHEN: Choking with fright, remorse and horror. Stephen claps hat on head and leaps over to the fireplace where he stands with shrugged shoulders, finny hands outspread, a painted smile on his face. Stephen closed his eyes to hear his boots crush crackling wrack and shells. STEPHEN: Comes to the table. STEPHEN: Cracking his fingers impatiently. STEPHEN: Dance of death. Stephen Dedalus and Lynch pass through the crowd close to the redcoats. Stephen Dedalus, behind him, uncovered as he entered. Stephen Dedalus, displeased and sleepy, leaned his arms on the top of the staircase and looked coldly at the shaking gurgling face that blessed him, equine in its length, and at the light untonsured hair, grained and hued like pale oak. Stephen Dedalus, professor and author. Stephen Dedalus stepped up, followed him wearily halfway and sat down on the edge of the gunrest, watching him still as he propped his mirror on the parapet, dipped the brush in the bowl and lathered cheeks and neck. Stephen Dedalus watched through the webbed window the lapidary’s fingers prove a timedulled chain. STEPHEN: Delightedly. Stephen, depressed by his own voice, said: —Do you remember the first day I went to your house after my mother’s death? STEPHEN: Devoutly. STEPHEN: Did I? Stephen dissented openly from Bloom’s views on the importance of dietary and civic selfhelp while Bloom dissented tacitly from Stephen’s views on the eternal affirmation of the spirit of man in literature. STEPHEN: Doesn’t matter a rambling damn. STEPHEN: Eagerly. STEPHEN: Ecstatically, to Cissy Caffrey. Stephen, eldest surviving male consubstantial heir of Simon Dedalus of Cork and Dublin and of Mary, daughter of Richard and Christina Goulding born Grier. STEPHEN: Et exaltabuntur cornua iusti. Stephen exclaimed. STEPHEN: Extends his arms. STEPHEN: Extends his hand to her smiling and chants to the air of the bloodoath in the Dusk of the Gods. Stephen fetched the loaf and the pot of honey and the buttercooler from the locker. Stephen filled again the three cups. Stephen filled a third cup, a spoonful of tea colouring faintly the thick rich milk. Stephen, flourishing the ashplant in his left hand, chants with joy the introit for paschal time. Stephen followed a lubber... Stephen freed his arm quietly. Stephen fumbles in his pocket and, taking out a banknote by its corner, hands it to her. STEPHEN: Gabbles with marionette jerks. Stephen glances behind at the squatted figure with its cap back to the front. Stephen, greeting, then all amort, followed a lubber jester, a wellkempt head, newbarbered, out of the vaulted cell into a shattering daylight of no thought. STEPHEN: Grimacing with head back, laughs loudly, clapping himself. STEPHEN: Groans. Stephen had not noticed her and shrugged his shoulders, merely remarking: —In this country people sell much more than she ever had and do a roaring trade. Stephen haled his upended valise to the table and sat down to wait. Stephen handed him the key. Stephen handed over the typed sheets, pointing to the title and signature. STEPHEN: Hands Bella a coin. STEPHEN: Hands him all his coins. STEPHEN: Hark! STEPHEN: He had three brothers, Gilbert, Edmund, Richard. STEPHEN: Here’s another for you. Stephen, his blood wooed by grace of language and gesture, blushed. Stephen, his throat itching, answered: —The fox burying his grandmother under a hollybush. STEPHEN: Ho! STEPHEN: Horrorstruck. STEPHEN: How do I stand you? STEPHEN: How is that? STEPHEN: In his trinity of black Wills, the villain shakebags, Iago, Richard Crookback, Edmund in King Lear, two bear the wicked uncles’ names. Stephen, in reply to a politely put query, said he didn’t sing it but launched out into praises of Shakespeare’s songs, at least of in or about that period, the lutenist Dowland who lived in Fetter lane near Gerard the herbalist, who anno ludendo hausi, Doulandus, an instrument he was contemplating purchasing from Mr Arnold Dolmetsch, whom B. did not quite recall though the name certainly sounded familiar, for sixtyfive guineas and Farnaby and son with their dux and comes conceits and Byrd William who played the virginals, he said, in the Queen’s chapel or anywhere else he found them and one Tomkins who made toys or airs and John Bull. STEPHEN: In the beginning was the word, in the end the world without end. STEPHEN: I seem to annoy them. Stephen jerked his thumb towards the window, saying: —That is God. STEPHEN: Kings and unicorns! Stephen laid the coin in her uneager hand. Stephen laid the shavingbowl on the locker. STEPHEN: Lamb of London, who takest away the sins of our world. Stephen laughed. STEPHEN: Laughs emptily. STEPHEN: Lecherous lynx, to la belle dame sans merci, Georgina Johnson, ad deam qui laetificat iuventutem meam. Stephen listened in scornful silence. Stephen looked down on a wide headless caubeen, hung on his ashplanthandle over his knee. Stephen looked on his hat, his stick, his boots. Stephen looks at it. STEPHEN: Looks behind. STEPHEN: Looks up to the sky. STEPHEN: Lucifer. STEPHEN: Mark me. STEPHEN: Mincingly. STEPHEN: Murmurs. STEPHEN: Murmurs. STEPHEN: Nervous, friendly, pulls himself up. STEPHEN: No! STEPHEN: Nods, smiling and laughing. STEPHEN: No, I flew. STEPHEN: Nothung! STEPHEN: No voice. Stephen, obviously addressed, looked down on the photo showing a large sized lady with her fleshy charms on evidence in an open fashion as she was in the full bloom of womanhood in evening dress cut ostentatiously low for the occasion to give a liberal display of bosom, with more than vision of breasts, her full lips parted and some perfect teeth, standing near, ostensibly with gravity, a piano on the rest of which was In Old Madrid, a ballad, pretty in its way, which was then all the vogue. Stephen of course started rather dizzily and stopped to return the compliment. Stephen of his own accord stopped for no special reason to look at the heap of barren cobblestones and by the light emanating from the brazier he could just make out the darker figure of the corporation watchman inside the gloom of the sentrybox. Stephen once by the reverend Charles Malone C. C., alone, in the church of the Three Patrons, Rathgar. STEPHEN: Out of it now. STEPHEN: Over his shoulder to Zoe. STEPHEN: Panting. STEPHEN: Pas seul! Stephen, patently crosstempered, repeated and shoved aside his mug of coffee or whatever you like to call it none too politely, adding: —We can’t change the country. Stephen picked it up and put it on. STEPHEN: Points. Stephen prayed. Stephen, prone, breathes to the stars. Stephen put the hat on his head. Stephen raised his eyes to the bold unheeding stare. Stephen raised the sheets in his hand. Stephen reached back and took the milkjug from the locker. Stephen rose. Stephen rustled the sheets again. Stephen said. Stephen said. Stephen said. Stephen said rudely. Stephen said with tingling energy. Stephen sat down. Stephen seated himself noiselessly before the princely presence. STEPHEN: See? Stephen seizes Florry and turns with her. Stephen’s embarrassed hand moved over the shells heaped in the cold stone mortar: whelks and money cowries and leopard shells: and this, whorled as an emir’s turban, and this, the scallop of saint James. Stephen shakes his head. Stephen’s hand, free again, went back to the hollow shells. Stephen, shielding the gaping wounds which the words had left in his heart, said very coldly: —I am not thinking of the offence to my mother. Stephen sketched a brief gesture. Stephen’s mother, emaciated, rises stark through the floor, in leper grey with a wreath of faded orangeblossoms and a torn bridal veil, her face worn and noseless, green with gravemould. STEPHEN: Spirit is willing but the flesh is weak. Stephen stands at the pianola on which sprawl his hat and ashplant. Stephen, Stephen, cut the bread even. STEPHEN: Stick, no. Stephen, still trembling at his soul’s cry, heard warm running sunlight and in the air behind him friendly words. Stephen stood at his post, gazing over the calm sea towards the headland. Stephen stood up. Stephen stood up and went over to the parapet. STEPHEN: Strangled with rage. STEPHEN: Stringendo He has hidden his own name, a fair name, William, in the plays, a super here, a clown there, as a painter of old Italy set his face in a dark corner of his canvas. Stephen suffered him to pull out and hold up on show by its corner a dirty crumpled handkerchief. STEPHEN: Swaying. Stephen, taking his ashplant from its leaningplace, followed them out and, as they went down the ladder, pulled to the slow iron door and locked it. Stephen, that is when the accosting figure came to close quarters, though he was not in an over sober state himself recognised Corley’s breath redolent of rotten cornjuice. STEPHEN: The fox crew, the cocks flew, The bells in heaven Were striking eleven. STEPHEN: The ghoul! STEPHEN: The harlot’s cry from street to street Shall weave Old Ireland’s windingsheet. Stephen, the youthful bard. Stephen threw two pennies on the soft heap. Stephen throws his ashplant on the table and seizes Zoe round the waist. STEPHEN: Throws up his hands. Stephen thrusts the ashplant on him and slowly holds out his hands, his head going back till both hands are a span from his breast, down turned, in planes intersecting, the fingers about to part, the left being higher. STEPHEN: Thursday. STEPHEN: To have or not to have that is the question. STEPHEN: To himself. STEPHEN: To Private Compton. Stephen totters, collapses, falls, stunned. Stephen touched the edges of the book. STEPHEN: Tries to move off. STEPHEN: Triumphaliter. Stephen turned and saw that the cold gaze which had measured him was not all unkind. Stephen turned away. Stephen turned boldly in his chair. Stephen turned his gaze from the sea and to the plump face with its smokeblue mobile eyes. Stephen turned in surprise. STEPHEN: Turns. Stephen turns and sees Bloom. STEPHEN: Vidi aquam egredientem de templo a latere dextro. STEPHEN: We have shrewridden Shakespeare and henpecked Socrates. Stephen went down Bedford row, the handle of the ash clacking against his shoulderblade. Stephen whirls giddily. Stephen, who confessed to still feeling poorly and fagged out, paused at the, for a moment, the door. Stephen, who was trying his dead best to yawn if he could, suffering from lassitude generally, replied: —To fill the ear of a cow elephant. STEPHEN: Why striking eleven? STEPHEN: With an effort. STEPHEN: With elaborate gestures, breathing deeply and slowly. STEPHEN: With exaggerated politeness. Stephen with hat ashplant frogsplits in middle highkicks with skykicking mouth shut hand clasp part under thigh. Stephen withstood the bane of miscreant eyes glinting stern under wrinkled brows. STEPHEN: You remember fairly accurately all my errors, boasts, mistakes. Step in. Stepping into the porch he doffed his hat, took the card from his pocket and tucked it again behind the leather headband. Steve boy, you’re going it some. Steve, thou art in a parlous way. Sticking them all over the place. Stick it in a chap’s eye in the tram. Stick one into Jerry. Sticks too like a summer cold, sore on the mouth. Still... Still always nice to hear. Still, an act of perfect contrition. Still an idea behind it. Still as regards return. Still better tell him. Still: but an itch of death is in them, to tell me in my ear a maudlin tale, urge me to wreak their will. Still candour compelled him to admit he had washed his wife’s undergarments when soiled in Holles street and women would and did too a man’s similar garments initialled with Bewley and Draper’s marking ink hers were, that is if they really loved him, that is to say, love me, love my dirty shirt. Still Captain Culler broke a window in the Kildare street club with a slog to square leg. Still David Sheehy beat him for south Meath. Still gardens have their drawbacks. Still harping on his daughter. Still, having eunuchs in their choir that was coming it a bit thick. Still hear it better here than in the bar though farther. Still he’d have to get someone to sod him after he died though he could dig his own grave. Still he had brains enough to make that corner in stamps. Still he knows his own business best. Still, he’s the best of that lot. Still he was a courteous old chap. Still his gaiety takes the harm out of it somehow, doesn’t it? Still hold her back. Still, I don’t know. Still if bullet only went through my coat get damages for shock, five hundred pounds. Still, I feel. Still if he works that paragraph. Still I got to know that young Dixon who dressed that sting for me in the Mater and now he’s in Holles street where Mrs Purefoy. Still in London. Still, I shouldn’t wonder if he did after all. —Still it’s solid food, his good genius urged, I’m a stickler for solid food, his one and only reason being not gormandising in the least but regular meals as the sine qua non for any kind of proper work, mental or manual. Still it’s the same fish perhaps old Micky Hanlon of Moore street ripped the guts out of making money hand over fist finger in fishes’ gills can’t write his name on a cheque think he was painting the landscape with his mouth twisted. Still it was a kind of language between us. Still I will help him in his fight. Still just then, being on tenterhooks, he desired the female’s room more than her company so it came as a genuine relief when the keeper made her a rude sign to take herself off. Still life. Still like you better untidy. Still no matter what the cause is from... Still no-one can give what he hasn’t got. Still, of course, you do get your Waterloo sometimes. Still perhaps: once in a way. —Still running, says he. —Still, says Bloom, on account of the poor woman, I mean his wife. Still seeking, he said: —When Fitzgibbon’s speech had ended John F Taylor rose to reply. Still, she might do worse. Still, she’s a dear girl. Still she was game. Still some might ooze out of an artery. Still, supposing he had his father’s gift as he more than suspected, it opened up new vistas in his mind such as Lady Fingall’s Irish industries, concert on the preceding Monday, and aristocracy in general. Still the blue eyes were glistening with hot tears that would well up so she kissed away the hurtness and shook her hand at Master Jacky the culprit and said if she was near him she wouldn’t be far from him, her eyes dancing in admonition. Still, the flowers are more poetical. Still their neigh can be very irritating. Still the name: Martha. Still the other brother lord Ardilaun has to change his shirt four times a day, they say. Still the plain straightforward question why a child of normally healthy parents and seemingly a healthy child and properly looked after succumbs unaccountably in early childhood though other children of the same marriage do not must certainly, in the poet’s words, give us pause. —Still there? Still there’s destiny in it, falling in love. Still they’d kiss all right if properly keyed up. Still they get their feed all right and their doss. Still they might like. Still to cultivate the acquaintance of someone of no uncommon calibre who could provide food for reflection would amply repay any small. Still, true to life also. Still two types there are you bob against. Still you can hear. Still you have to get rid of it someway. Still you learn something. Still, you never know. Stimulate the caloric. Stink gripped his trembling breath: pungent meatjuice, slush of greens. Stinks like a polecat. Stomachs like breadgraters. —Stone ginger, Davy Byrne added civilly. Stonewall or fivebarred gate put her mount to it. Stop! Stop. Stop. Stop! Stop. —Stop! Stop! Stop. Stop! Stopabloom! Stop and say a word: about the funeral perhaps. Stop Bloom! Stopgap. Stophim on the corner! Stop or I’ll tell the missus on you. Stopped. Stopped again. Stopped in Citron’s saint Kevin’s parade. Stopped short never to go again when the old. Stopped with Dick Tivy. Stopperrobber! Stop! says Joe. Stop that and begin worse. Stop them from fighting! Stop thief! Stop twirling your thumbs and have a good old thunk. Stout lady does be with you in the brown costume. Stowing in the wreaths probably. Straight on her pins anyway not like the other. —Strange but true, Martin Cunningham added. Strange feeling it would be. Strange he never saw his real country. Strange how they take to me. Strange kind of music that last night. Strange moment for the mother too. Strange name. Strangers in my house, bad manners to them! Straw hat in sunlight. Stream of life. Streams of tendency and eons they worship. Street angel and house devil. Street of harlots. Street of harlots. Street of harlots after. Streetwalking and soliciting. Strength of character had never been Reggy Wylie’s strong point and he who would woo and win Gerty MacDowell must be a man among men. Strictly confidential. Strictly confidential. Striding past Finn’s hotel Cashel Boyle O’Connor Fitzmaurice Tisdall Farrell stared through a fierce eyeglass across the carriages at the head of Mr M. E. Solomons in the window of the Austro-Hungarian viceconsulate. Strike me silly, said Costello, a low fellow who was fuddled. Strike up a ballad. Strings. Strong as a brood mare some of those horsey women. Strong curtain. Strongly. Strong man grapses woman’s wrist. Strong pair of arms. Struggle for life is the law of existence but but human philirenists, notably the tsar and the king of England, have invented arbitration. Stubborn as a mule! Stuck. Stuck on the pane two flies buzzed, stuck. Stuck, the flies buzzed. Stuck together! Stuff them up with meat and drink. Stuffy it was. Stunned like, seeing as how no shiners is acoming. Stupefies them first. Stylish coat, beyond a doubt. Stylish kind of coat with that roll collar, warm for a day like this, looks like blanketcloth. Subject, what is in this snuffbox? Subleader for his death written this long time perhaps. Subsequently being not quite so down in the mouth after the two and six he got he informed Stephen about a fellow by the name of Bags Comisky that he said Stephen knew well out of Fullam’s, the shipchandler’s, bookkeeper there that used to be often round in Nagle’s back with O’Mara and a little chap with a stutter the name of Tighe. Subsequently he enclosed a bloom of edelweiss culled on the heights, as he said, in my honour. Substantially. Substituting Bloom for Stephen Blephen would have passed successively through the preparatory, junior, middle and senior grades of the intermediate and through the matriculation, first arts, second arts and arts degree courses of the royal university. Substituting Stephen for Bloom Stoom would have passed successively through a dame’s school and the high school. Success for us is the death of the intellect and of the imagination. Successively, in descending helotic order: Poverty: that of the outdoor hawker of imitation jewellery, the dun for the recovery of bad and doubtful debts, the poor rate and deputy cess collector. Successor to my famous brother! Such a bad headache. Such an appeal will touch him. Such as? Such as never? Such as not? Such a... what should he say?... such a queenly mien. Such fleshy parts are the product of careful nurture. Such growling you never heard as they let off between them. Such is life in an outhouse. Such persons always have. Sucking duck eggs by God till further orders. Sucking, they scatter slowly. Suck your blood dry, they does. Sudden bent. Suddenly happied he jumped up and reached in a stride John Eglinton’s desk. Suddenly he made off like a bounding hare, ears flung back, chasing the shadow of a lowskimming gull. Suddenly he turned to Stephen: —He knows you. Suffered untold misery. Suffer then. SUFFICIENT FOR THE DAY... Sufficient for the day is the newspaper thereof. Sufflaminandus sum. Suicide. Suit for damages by legal influence or simulation of assault with evidence of injuries sustained selfinflicted, not impossibly. Suits her, with a little jessamine mixed. Sully my innocence! Sulphate of copper poison SO4 or something in some dried peas he remembered reading of in a cheap eatinghouse somewhere but he couldn’t remember when it was or where. Sulphur. Sulphur dung of lions! Sumptuous and stagnant exaggeration of murder. Sunburst on the titlepage. Sundown, gunfire for the men to cross the lines. Sunk by war specials. Sunk though he be beneath the watery floor. Sunlight through the slats of the Venetian blind. Sun or wind. Sun’s heat it is. Sunwarm silk. Suppose. Suppose. Supposed to be well connected. Suppose he gave her money. Suppose he hit me. Suppose he lost the pin of his. Suppose he was consumptive. Suppose I spoke to her. Suppose it’s ever so many millions of tiny grains blown across. Suppose it’s the only time we cross legs, seated. Suppose I when I was? Suppose she did Pygmalion and Galatea what would she say first? Suppose she does? Suppose she was gone when he? Suppose she were the? Suppose she wouldn’t let herself be vaccinated again. Suppose that communal kitchen years to come perhaps. Suppose there’s some connection. Suppose they wouldn’t feel anything after. Suppose you got up the wrong side of the bed or came too quick with your best girl. Sure? Sure enough the castle car drove up with Martin on it and Jack Power with him and a fellow named Crofter or Crofton, pensioner out of the collector general’s, an orangeman Blackburn does have on the registration and he drawing his pay or Crawford gallivanting around the country at the king’s expense. Sure he has a small bank balance somewhere, government sit. Sure he’s not down in Strasburg terrace with his aunt Sally? Sure, he’s out in John of God’s off his head, poor man. —Sure I’m after seeing him not five minutes ago, says Alf, as plain as a pikestaff. Surely, there ought to be. Sure, the blooming thing is all over. Sure they wanted me to join in with the mots. Sure thing. Sure to know someone on the gate. —Sure we ought to, the old woman said, and I’m ashamed I don’t speak the language myself. —Sure, you’d burst the tympanum of her ear, man, Mr Dedalus said through smoke aroma, with an organ like yours. Sure you won’t, ma’amsir. Surfeit. Surprise, horror, loathing were depicted on all faces while he eyed them with a ghostly grin. Suspiciously. SUSY: Mamma, the beeftea is fizzing over! Swagger around livery stables. Swallow? Swans from Anna Liffey swim down here sometimes to preen themselves. —Sweat of my brow, says Joe. Sweeeet song. Sweep! Sweep for that matter. —Sweet almond oil and tincture of benzoin, Mr Bloom said, and then orangeflower water... Sweet and cheap: soon sour. Sweet Ann, I take it, was hot in the blood. Sweet are the sweets. Sweetheart, goodbye! Sweetheart, goodbye! Sweet lemony wax. Sweet name too: caramel. Sweets of sin. —Sweets of Sin, he said, tapping on it. Sweets to the. Sweet tea miss Kennedy having poured with milk plugged both two ears with little fingers. Swell blowout. Swell of her calf. Swell the bust. Sweny’s in Lincoln place. SWENY: Three and a penny, please. Swiftly rectly creaking rectly rectly he was rectly gone. Swill till eleven. Swindled them all, skivvies and badhachs from the county Meath, ay, and his own kidney too. Swindle in it somewhere. —Swindling the peasants, says the citizen, and the poor of Ireland. Swish and soft flop her stays made on the bed. Switch off the current, will you? Swurls, he says. Symbol of the apostles in the mass for pope Marcellus, the voices blended, singing alone loud in affirmation: and behind their chant the vigilant angel of the church militant disarmed and menaced her heresiarchs. Symbols too of beauty and of power. Symmetry under a cemetery wall. Sympathetic human man he is. Sympathetic listener. Synge has left off wearing black to be like nature. Synge has promised me an article for Dana too. Ta an bad ar an tir. Table: able. Tableau! Tableau! Table talk. Tail gone now. Taim in mo shagart. Tainted game. Take! —Take a bit of doing, boss, retaliated that rough diamond palpably a bit peeved in response to the foregoing truism. Take a handful of hay and wipe yourself. Take all, keep all. —Take a what? says I. Take care they didn’t lift anything off him. Take down his trousers without loss of time. Take her for me. Take him in tow, platter face and a large apron. Take me out of my way. Taken a few years since. Taken a little more than is good for him. Take no notice. —Take no notice, miss Kennedy rejoined. Take off that white hat. Take off the rough dirt. Take one Spanish onion. Take out sheet notepaper, envelope: unconcerned. —Take page four, advertisement for Bransome’s coffee, let us say. Takes it for granted we’re going to pop off first. Take some slips from the counter going out. Takes the biscuit, and talking about bunions. Take that! Take that in your right hand and repeat after me the following words. Take the train there tomorrow. Take this. Take thou this noble. Taking a man from another woman. Taking it easy with hand under his cheek. Taking my motives he twined and turned them. Taking off his flat spaugs and the walk. Taking Stephen on one side he had the customary doleful ditty to tell. Taking what belongs to us by right. Talbot asked simply, bending forward. Talbot repeated: —Through the dear might of Him that walked the waves, Through the dear might... Talbot slid his closed book into his satchel. Tales of the bench and assizes and annals of the bluecoat school. Talk. Talk. Talk about apple dumplings, piuttosto. Talk: as if that would mend matters. Talking about hanging, I’ll show you something you never saw. Talking about new Ireland he ought to go and get a new dog so he ought. —Talking about the invincibles, he said, did you see that some hawkers were up before the recorder... —Talking about violent exercise, says Alf, were you at that Keogh-Bennett match? Talking of one thing or another. Talking through his bloody hat. Talk that to someone else, Stevie: a pickmeup. Tally ho. Tame essence of Wilde. Tanderagee wants the facts and means to get them. Tankard loved the song that Mina. Tankards and miss Kennedy. Tank one believed: miss Kenn when she: that doll he was: she doll: the tank. Tanks you. Tan shoes. Tansy and pennyroyal. Tantalising for the poor dead. Tante belle cose! Tap. Tap. Tap. Tap. Tap. Tap. Tap. Tap. Tap. Tap. Tap. Tap. Tap. Tap. Tap. Tap. Tap. Tap. Tap. Tap. Tap. Tap. Tap. Tap. Tap. Tap. Tap. Tap. Tap. Tap. Tap. Tap. Tap. Tap. Tap. Tap. Tap. Tap. Tap. Tap. Tap. Tap. Tap. Tap blind walked tapping by the tap the curbstone tapping, tap by tap. Tape measurements will be taken next your skin. Tap —Very, Mr Dedalus said, staring hard at a headless sardine. Tap with it: they do. Tara. Tara. Tara: bom bom bom. Tara street. Tara tara. Tarbarrels and bonfires were lighted along the coastline of the four seas on the summits of the Hill of Howth, Three Rock Mountain, Sugarloaf, Bray Head, the mountains of Mourne, the Galtees, the Ox and Donegal and Sperrin peaks, the Nagles and the Bograghs, the Connemara hills, the reeks of M’Gillicuddy, Slieve Aughty, Slieve Bernagh and Slieve Bloom. Tare and ages, what way would I be resting at all, he muttered thickly, and I tramping Dublin this while back with my share of songs and himself after me the like of a soulth or a bullawurrus? Taree tara. —Tarentum, sir. Tarnally dog gone my shins if this beent the bestest puttiest longbreak yet. Taste it better because I’m not thirsty. —Taste it, sir, she said. Tastes? Tastes all different for him. Tastes fuller this weather with the chill off. Tattered pages. —Tatters! —Tattoo, the exhibitor explained. Taunted them still, bending, suspending, with wilful eyes. T. Brangan, O. S. A.; the rev. T. Caulfield Irwin. Tea. Tea. Tea. Tea. Tea before you put milk in. Teach your grandmother how to milk ducks. Tear it limb from limb. Tears gushed from the eyes of the dissipated host. Tears of molten butter fall from his eyes on to the scone. Technic. Tee dash ar most courageous mariner. Teeth getting worse and worse. Telegram! Telegram! —Telegram! he said. Telegraph. —Telegraph! Tell about places you have been, strange customs. Tell a cram, that. Tell her a ghost story in bed to make her sleep. Tell her I was axing at her. Tell her: more and more: all. Tell him a tale of woe about arrears of rent and a sick wife and a squad of kids and, faith, he’ll dissolve in tears on the bench. —Tell him go to hell, the editor said promptly. Tell him if he smokes he won’t grow. Tell him I’m Boylan with impatience. Tell him, says he, I dare him, says he, and I doubledare him to send you round here again or if he does, says he, I’ll have him summonsed up before the court, so I will, for trading without a licence. Tell him silly Milly sends my best respects. Tell him that straight from the stable. Tell me all. Tell me I want to. —Tell me, Mulligan, Stephen said quietly. —Tell me now, Stephen said, poking the boy’s shoulder with the book, what is a pier. Tell me something to amuse me, smut or a bloody good ghoststory or a line of poetry, quick, quick, quick! Tell me that. Tell me the word, mother, if you know now. Tell me who made the world. Tell mother you’ll be there. Tell Pat you saw me, won’t you? —Tell that to a fool, says the citizen. Tell that to the oxy chap downstairs and touch him for a guinea. Tell us. —Tell us a story, sir. Tell us, Florry. —Tell us if you’re worth your salt and be damned to you, Paddy Leonard said. Tell us in plain words. Tell us news. Tell us, there’s a dear. —Tell us who is your sweetheart, spoke Edy Boardman. Tell you what it is. —Tell you what, M’Coy said. Temple, two lunches. —Temporary insanity, of course, Martin Cunningham said decisively. Tempting fruit. Tempting poor simple males. Ten bob I got for Molly’s combings when we were on the rocks in Holles street. Tenderly, as he slips on her finger a ruby ring. Tenderly Bloom over liverless bacon saw the tightened features strain. Tenderness it welled: slow, swelling, full it throbbed. Ten, did you say? Ten minutes. —Ten minutes, Martin Cunningham said, looking at his watch. Tenors get wom. Tenors get women by the score. Ten shillings. Ten shillings? Ten shillings. Ten shillings? Ten shillings! Ten shillings a time. Ten shillings for the gardener. Tension makes them nervous. Tentacles: octopus. The carcass lay on his path. The caretaker blinked up at one of the sepulchres they passed. The caretaker hung his thumbs in the loops of his gold watchchain and spoke in a discreet tone to their vacant smiles. The caretaker moved away a few paces and put on his hat. The caretaker put the papers in his pocket. The car jingles tooraloom round the corner of the tooraloom lane. The carriage climbed more slowly the hill of Rutland square. The carriage galloped round a corner: stopped. The carriage halted short. The carriage heeled over and back, their four trunks swaying. The carriage moved on through the drove. The carriage, passing the open drains and mounds of rippedup roadway before the tenement houses, lurched round the corner and, swerving back to the tramtrack, rolled on noisily with chattering wheels. The carriage rattled swiftly along Blessington street. The carriage steered left for Finglas road. The carriage swerved from the tramtrack to the smoother road past Watery lane. The carriage turned again its stiff wheels and their trunks swayed gently. The carriage wheeling by Farrell’s statue united noiselessly their unresisting knees. The castle car wheeled empty into upper Exchange street. The catastrophe was terrific and instantaneous in its effect. The cat, having cleaned all her fur, returned to the meatstained paper, nosed at it and stalked to the door. The cat mewed in answer and stalked again stiffly round a leg of the table, mewing. The cat mewed to him. The cat-o’-nine-tails. The cat’s ramble through the slag. The cat walked stiffly round a leg of the table with tail on high. The cat went up in soft bounds. The distinguished scientist Herr Professor Luitpold Blumenduft tendered medical evidence to the effect that the instantaneous fracture of the cervical vertebrae and consequent scission of the spinal cord would, according to the best approved tradition of medical science, be calculated to inevitably produce in the human subject a violent ganglionic stimulus of the nerve centres of the genital apparatus, thereby causing the elastic pores of the corpora cavernosa to rapidly dilate in such a way as to instantaneously facilitate the flow of blood to that part of the human anatomy known as the penis or male organ resulting in the phenomenon which has been denominated by the faculty a morbid upwards and outwards philoprogenitive erection in articulo mortis per diminutionem capitis. —The divine afflatus, Mr O’Madden Burke said. The individual whose visual organs while the above was going on were at this juncture commencing to exhibit symptoms of animation was as astute if not astuter than any man living and anybody that conjectured the contrary would have found themselves pretty speedily in the wrong shop. The indoor exercises, formerly intermittently practised, subsequently abandoned, prescribed in Eugen Sandow’s Physical Strength and How to Obtain It which, designed particularly for commercial men engaged in sedentary occupations, were to be made with mental concentration in front of a mirror so as to bring into play the various families of muscles and produce successively a pleasant rigidity, a more pleasant relaxation and the most pleasant repristination of juvenile agility. Their blood is in me, their lusts my waves. Their bodies plunge. Their butteries and larders. Their carriage began to move, creaking and swaying. Their character. Their conversation accordingly became general and all agreed that that was a fact. Their deadly coil they grasp: yea, and therein they lead to Erebus whatsoever wight hath done a deed of blood for I will on nowise suffer it even so saith the Lord. Their dog ambled about a bank of dwindling sand, trotting, sniffing on all sides. Their Eldorado. Their eyes grew bigger as the lines were repeated. Their eyes knew their years of wandering and, patient, knew the dishonours of their flesh. Their eyes watched him. Their eyes were probing her mercilessly but with a brave effort she sparkled back in sympathy as she glanced at her new conquest for them to see. Their frugal meal. Their full buck eyes regarded him as he went by, amid the sweet oaten reek of horsepiss. Their full slow eyes belied the words, the gestures eager and unoffending, but knew the rancours massed about them and knew their zeal was vain. Their green and gold beaconjars too heavy to stir. Their heelmarks will stamp the Brusselette carpet you bought at Wren’s auction. The Irish Beekeeper. The Irish Caruso-Garibaldi was in superlative form and his stentorian notes were heard to the greatest advantage in the timehonoured anthem sung as only our citizen can sing it. The Irish Independent, if you please, founded by Parnell to be the workingman’s friend. The Irishman’s house is his coffin. Their life, thought, speech are lent them by males. Their likes: their breaths, too, sweetened with tea and jam, their bracelets tittering in the struggle. Their little frolic after meals. Their lives. Their mudcabins and their shielings by the roadside were laid low by the batteringram and the Times rubbed its hands and told the whitelivered Saxons there would soon be as few Irish in Ireland as redskins in America. Their names are Anne Kearns and Florence MacCabe. Their natural craving. Their paintspeckled hats wag. Their paler smaller negroid hands jingle the twingtwang wires. Their Pali book we tried to pawn. The irreparability of the past: once at a performance of Albert Hengler’s circus in the Rotunda, Rutland square, Dublin, an intuitive particoloured clown in quest of paternity had penetrated from the ring to a place in the auditorium where Bloom, solitary, was seated and had publicly declared to an exhilarated audience that he Bloom was his the clown’s papa. The irrepressible Bloom, who also had a shrewd suspicion that the old stager went out on a manœuvre after the counterattraction in the shape of a female who however had disappeared to all intents and purposes, could by straining just perceive him, when duly refreshed by his rum puncheon exploit, gaping up at the piers and girders of the Loop line rather out of his depth as of course it was all radically altered since his last visit and greatly improved. Then spake young Stephen orgulous of mother Church that would cast him out of her bosom, of law of canons, of Lilith, patron of abortions, of bigness wrought by wind of seeds of brightness or by potency of vampires mouth to mouth or, as Virgilius saith, by the influence of the occident or by the reek of moonflower or an she lie with a woman which her man has but lain with, effectu secuto, or peradventure in her bath according to the opinions of Averroes and Moses Maimonides. Then they began to have a few irascible words when it waxed hotter, both, needless to say, appealing to the listeners who followed the passage of arms with interest so long as they didn’t indulge in recriminations and come to blows. Then they could talk about her till they went blue in the face, Bertha Supple too, and Edy, little spitfire, because she would be twentytwo in November. Then they follow: dropping into a hole, one after the other. Then they’ll all see it in the paper and read my name printed and pa’s name. Then, though it had poured seven showers, we were neither of us a penny the worse. Then too far. Then, turning to Father Cowley with a nod, he muttered sneeringly: —That’s a pretty garment, isn’t it, for a summer’s day? Then, unable to repress his merriment, he rocks to and fro, arms akimbo, and sings with broad rollicking humour: O, the poor little fellow Hihihihihis legs they were yellow He was plump, fat and heavy and brisk as a snake But some bloody savage To graize his white cabbage He murdered Nell Flaherty’s duckloving drake. The nursingwoman answered him and said that that woman was in throes now full three days and that it would be a hard birth unneth to bear but that now in a little it would be. Then walking slowly forward he read the letter again, murmuring here and there a word. —Then what is it? Then wheels were heard from in front, turning: then nearer: then horses’ hoofs. Then who’d wash up all the plates and forks? Then, with the water running off him, he got into an old smock and skirt that had belonged to his grandmother and bought a grammar of the bulls’ language to study but he could never learn a word of it except the first personal pronoun which he copied out big and got off by heart and if ever he went out for a walk he filled his pockets with chalk to write it upon what took his fancy, the side of a rock or a teahouse table or a bale of cotton or a corkfloat. Then with those Röntgen rays searchlight you could. Then wotted he nought of that other land which is called Believe-on-Me, that is the land of promise which behoves to the king Delightful and shall be for ever where there is no death and no birth neither wiving nor mothering at which all shall come as many as believe on it? There was a sort of scholars along either side the board, that is to wit, Dixon yclept junior of saint Mary Merciable’s with other his fellows Lynch and Madden, scholars of medicine, and the franklin that hight Lenehan and one from Alba Longa, one Crotthers, and young Stephen that had mien of a frere that was at head of the board and Costello that men clepen Punch Costello all long of a mastery of him erewhile gested and of all them, reserved young Stephen, he was the most drunken that demanded still of more mead and beside the meek sir Leopold. There was a time I was as good as the next fellow anyhow. There was no message evidently, as he took particular notice. There was none to come up to her for fun. There was no response forthcoming to the suggestion however, such as it was, Stephen’s mind’s eye being too busily engaged in repicturing his family hearth the last time he saw it with his sister Dilly sitting by the ingle, her hair hanging down, waiting for some weak Trinidad shell cocoa that was in the sootcoated kettle to be done so that she and he could drink it with the oatmealwater for milk after the Friday herrings they had eaten at two a penny with an egg apiece for Maggy, Boody and Katey, the cat meanwhile under the mangle devouring a mess of eggshells and charred fish heads and bones on a square of brown paper, in accordance with the third precept of the church to fast and abstain on the days commanded, it being quarter tense or if not, ember days or something like that. —There was one woman, Nosey Flynn said, hid herself in a clock to find out what they do be doing. There was something on his mind, I saw. There was that in her young voice that told that she was not a one to be lightly trifled with. There was the allimportant question and she was dying to know was he a married man or a widower who had lost his wife or some tragedy like the nobleman with the foreign name from the land of song had to have her put into a madhouse, cruel only to be kind. There was the unanimous opinion that there was none to come up to her and suffice it to say in a place of worship for music of a sacred character there was a generally voiced desire for an encore. There was weeping and gnashing of teeth over that. There were equally excellent opportunities for vacationists in the home island, delightful sylvan spots for rejuvenation, offering a plethora of attractions as well as a bracing tonic for the system in and around Dublin and its picturesque environs even, Poulaphouca to which there was a steamtram, but also farther away from the madding crowd in Wicklow, rightly termed the garden of Ireland, an ideal neighbourhood for elderly wheelmen so long as it didn’t come down, and in the wilds of Donegal where if report spoke true the coup d’œil was exceedingly grand though the lastnamed locality was not easily getatable so that the influx of visitors was not as yet all that it might be considering the signal benefits to be derived from it while Howth with its historic associations and otherwise, Silken Thomas, Grace O’Malley, George IV, rhododendrons several hundred feet above sealevel was a favourite haunt with all sorts and conditions of men especially in the spring when young men’s fancy, though it had its own toll of deaths by falling off the cliffs by design or accidentally, usually, by the way, on their left leg, it being only about three quarters of an hour’s run from the pillar. The various colours significant of various degrees of vitality white, yellow, crimson, vermilion, cinnabar: their degrees of brilliancy: their magnitudes revealed up to and including the 7th: their positions: the waggoner’s star: Walsingham way: the chariot of David: the annular cinctures of Saturn: the condensation of spiral nebulae into suns: the interdependent gyrations of double suns: the independent synchronous discoveries of Galileo, Simon Marius, Piazzi, Le Verrier, Herschel, Galle: the systematisations attempted by Bode and Kepler of cubes of distances and squares of times of revolution: the almost infinite compressibility of hirsute comets and their vast elliptical egressive and reentrant orbits from perihelion to aphelion: the sidereal origin of meteoric stones: the Libyan floods on Mars about the period of the birth of the younger astroscopist: the annual recurrence of meteoric showers about the period of the feast of S. Lawrence martyr, 10 August: the monthly recurrence known as the new moon with the old moon in her arms: the posited influence of celestial on human bodies: the appearance of a star 1st magnitude of exceeding brilliancy dominating by night and day a new luminous sun generated by the collision and amalgamation in incandescence of two nonluminous exsuns about the period of the birth of William Shakespeare over delta in the recumbent neversetting constellation of Cassiopeia and of a star 2nd magnitude of similar origin but of lesser brilliancy which had appeared in and disappeared from the constellation of the Corona Septentrionalis about the period of the birth of Leopold Bloom and of other stars of presumably similar origin which had effectively or presumably appeared in and disappeared from the constellation of Andromeda about the period of the birth of Stephen Dedalus, and in and from the constellation of Auriga some years after the birth and death of Rudolph Bloom, junior, and in and from other constellations some years before or after the birth or death of other persons: the attendant phenomena of eclipses, solar and lunar, from immersion to emersion, abatement of wind, transit of shadow, taciturnity of winged creatures, emergence of nocturnal or crepuscular animals, persistence of infernal light, obscurity of terrestrial waters, pallor of human beings.
